descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems after a record is added to a service delivery location registry.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Notification Add
descriptive.p: Good Health Hospital is opening a new bone marrow transplant program. In preparation for putting the program in service the data entry clerk adds the new service delivery locations to the hospital's location registry for the Bone Marrow Transplant Unit patient rooms, operating theater, recovery room and Bone Marrow Transplant outpatient clinic. The registry then sends notifications to location registry tracking systems.

intref.refName: Service Delivery Location Event Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems after a record is revised in a service delivery location registry.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Notification Edit
descriptive.p: A wing of the Good Health Hospital has undergone renovation and some patient locations need to be updated in the service delivery location registry (e.g. some rooms now can be used for patients needing particular services, such as isolation). The data entry clerk updates the records in the hospital's location registry and the registry sends notifications to location registry tracking systems.

intref.refName: Service Delivery Location Event Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems after an erroneous record in a service delivery location registry has been nullified. Note, addressing a duplicate record is described in storyboard.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Notification Nullify
descriptive.p: The Good Health Hospital is preparing to open a new wing of the hospital in a few weeks and the new hospital locations need to be added to the system. The system administrator adds the new service delivery location records to the hospital's location registry and the system notifies location registry tracking systems. Later that day the system administrator learns that one of the locations was incorrect so the record is nullified in the location registry and a notification is sent to location registry tracking systems.

intref.refName: Service Delivery Location Event Nullify Notification

story.name: Service Delivery Location Notification Resolve Duplicates

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates resolving duplicate records in a location registry. The incorrect registration is marked "obsolete" and linked to the surviving registration.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Notification Resolve Duplicates

story.descriptive: The Good Health Hospital includes independent pharmacies in its service delivery location registry so practitioners can send outpatient scripts for patients who are being discharged. Doctor Primary noticed that the Good Neighbor Pharmacy on Village Avenue was listed separately under its old name of Neighborhood Pharmacy. The location registry data analyst marked the record for Neighborhood Pharmacy as obsolete and linked it to the record for Good Neighbor Pharmacy. The registry then sent a notification to all location registry trackers.

intref.refName: Service Delivery Location Event Obsolete Notification

story.name: Service Delivery Location Query Find Candidates

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates querying a location registry for a list of records matching a set of location details.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Query Find Candidates

story.descriptive: Eve Everywoman called her health insurer to find a dermatology clinic where she could have a mole removed. The clerk entered Eve's home zip code, service delivery location type of Dermatology clinic, statusCode of active, specified that matches should be weighted by distance from Eve's home zip code and initiated a to the insurer's service delivery location registry. In less than a minute a was returned listing 20 dermatology clinics near Eve's home address.

story.name: Service Delivery Location Query Get Details

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates querying a location registry to get detailed information for a registered location.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Query Get Details
descriptive.p: On Saturday evening the physician on duty at Good Health Hospital asked the ward clerk to contact the Home Health Care Clinic so she could discuss arranging for home health nurse visits after Mr. Everyman is discharged. The ward clerk entered the identifier for Home Health Care Clinic and initiated a to the enterprise service delivery location registry. The registry immediately returned a which included the name and telephone number for the weekend evening contact person for Home Health Care Clinic.

story.name: Service Delivery Location Query Get Identifiers

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates querying a location registry to get all identifiers for a registered location.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Query Get Identifiers

story.descriptive: The logistics clerk for Good Health Hospital, Connor Comrade, needed to place a supply order with Seventh Level Logistics for GHH's Three Rivers Satellite Clinic. The order form required the identifier assigned by Seventh Level Logistics to the delivery site. Connor initiated a to the regional service delivery location registry with the regional registry identifier assigned to Three Rivers Satellite Clinic. The registry responded immediately with a which included all identifiers assigned to the clinic by other organizations including Seventh Level Logistics.

story.name: Service Delivery Location Request Add
story.descriptive: This storyboard demonstrates a local location registry sending a request to an enterprise (or national or regional) location registry to add a new record to the enterprise location registry. The enterprise location registry system will respond with a confirmation and the enterprise identifier for the new location record, or it will respond with a rejection and the reason for the rejection.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Request Add Accepted
descriptive.p: Good Health Hospital is opening a new bone marrow transplant program. In preparation for putting the program in service the data entry clerk added the new service delivery locations to the hospital's location registry for the Bone Marrow Transplant Unit patient rooms, operating theater, recovery room and Bone Marrow Transplant outpatient clinic. After Good Health Hospital officially opened the new program it sent a interaction from its local service delivery location registry to the regional service delivery location registry requesting that its Bone Marrow Transplant outpatient clinic be added to the regional registry.

The regional service delivery location registry accepted the request, added the GHH Bone Marrow Transplant outpatient clinic to the regional registry and returned a interaction with the identifier assigned to the clinic for by regional registry.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Request Add Rejected
descriptive.p: Good Health Hospital is opening a new bone marrow transplant program. In preparation for putting the program in service the data entry clerk added the new service delivery locations to the hospital's location registry for the Bone Marrow Transplant Unit patient rooms, operating theater, recovery room and Bone Marrow Transplant outpatient clinic. After Good Health Hospital officially opened the new program it sent a interaction from its local service delivery location registry to the regional service delivery location registry requesting that its Bone Marrow Transplant outpatient clinic be added to the regional registry.

The regional service delivery location registry received the request but rejected it because it could not validate the code used to classify the location it as a bone marrow transplant clinic. The regional registry returned a interaction with a Detected Issue of "invalid code."

story.name: Service Delivery Location Request Edit
story.descriptive: This storyboard demonstrates a local location registry sending a request to an enterprise (or national or regional) location registry to revise information for a record in the enterprise location registry. The enterprise location registry system will respond with a confirmation of the information update, or it will respond with a rejection and the reason for the rejection

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Request Edit Accepted
descriptive.p: Good Health Hospital recently converted its Pediatric Care Unit to a Pediatric Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. The location registry system manager updated the record in the hospital's location registry and initiated a to the regional service delivery location registry.

The regional service delivery location registry accepted the request, revised the classification of the location and returned a interaction with a copy of the revised record from the regional registry.

descriptive.name: Service Delivery Location Request Edit Rejected
descriptive.p: Good Health Hospital recently converted its Pediatric Care Unit to a Pediatric Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. The data clerk updated the record in the hospital's location registry and initiated a to the regional service delivery location registry.

The regional service delivery location registry received the request but rejected it because it the data clerk was not listed as someone authorized to change location records for Good Health Hospital in the regional registry. The regional registry returned a interaction with a Detected Issue of "unauthorized author."

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Activate R-MIM defines the payload message used for state-transition requests and notifications for adding new records in a service delivery location registry.

The ServiceDeliveryLocation class is the entry point to the R-MIM. It represents a role played by a Place at which services may be provided by an Organization. Note that providing services is not synonymous with "ownership." A given Place can play multiple service delivery location roles each with its own attributes. For example, a Podiatric clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number. A ServiceDeliveryLocation can exist within a hierarchy of other service delivery locations; for example, the Good Health Hospital contains the Emergency Ward which contains Emergency Bed Location A. These associations can be conveyed through the part and partOf role links.

A bounded physical place or site with its contained structures, if any. A place may be natural or man-made. Its geographic position may or may not be constant. A mobile Place such as an ambulance would be conveyed by setting mobileInd to true. A Place can exist within a hierarchy of other places. The focal Place can be associated with a Place that contains it through the LocatedEntityPartOf role; for example, a wing is part of a building. The focal Place can be associated with a Place contained within it through the LocatedEntityHasParts role; for example, a wing contains rooms.
This is the (optional) organization that provides services at the ServiceDeliveryLocation.

The geographic coordinates of a ServiceDeliveryLocation can be conveyed in an A_SpatialCoordinate observation. Note that since a Place can be mobile it is possible that the ServiceDeliveryLocation might subjectOf of a sequence of spatial coordinate observations.
The locationOf participation can associate a ServiceDeliveryLocation with the types of services (ServiceDefinition) that are available at that location.

A ServiceDeliveryLocation may have multiple means by which it may be contacted for various reasons. For example, there may be different contact persons and telephone numbers for scheduling appointments, renewing prescriptions, emergency contacts outside of normal working hours. These contact parties are associated with the ServiceDeliveryLocation through a directAuthorityOver role link. The type of contact is characterized by the ContactParty.code attribute.

External organizations such as payers and regulators may assign their own identifiers to service delivery locations. This type of identifier is conveyed in an IdentifiedLocation role associated with the ServiceDeliveryLocation through an indirectAuthorityOver role link. The organization using the identifier is identified by name in the IdentifierOrganization entity.

A ServiceDeliveryLocation may be located within a geographic region that falls under the jurisdiction of a territorial authority. For example, the Calgary Regional Health Authority has authority over the territory "Region 4 of Alberta" in matters of health. The ServiceDeliveryLocation is associated with a TerritorialAuthority through an indirectAuthority role link.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Revise R-MIM defines the payload message used for state-transition requests and notifications for revising records in a service delivery location registry.
The Service Delivery Location Revise R-MIM differs from the Service Delivery Location Activate R-MIM in the following ways:

list.item: ServiceDeliveryLocation - the statusCode attribute can take on any of the RoleStatusNormal values (excludes nullify) instead of the fixed value of "active"
Update Mode - the revise message implements update mode to convey changes and the R-MIM specifies allowed update modes for certain attributes and associations.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Event Nullify R-MIM defines the payload for a state-transition notification after a record in a service delivery location registry has been nullified.

list.item: Mandatory id
Mandatory code
Required name
Mandatory statusCode with fixed value of nullified
Non-mandatory serviceProviderOrganization association
Non-mandatory location association

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Details R-MIM defines the payload message used for query responses that return a complete or partial record from a service delivery location registry.

The Service Delivery Location Details R-MIM differs from the Service Delivery Location Activate R-MIM by allowing the ServiceDeliveryLocationstatusCode attribute to take on any RoleStatus value instead of being fixed as "active."

rmim.name: Service Delivery Location Event Find Candidates Response

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Location Registry Find Candidates Response R-MIM defines the payload message used to return records from a service delivery location registry in response to a find candidates query. Each record includes an observation reporting how well the record matched the query parameters.
The Location Registry Find Candidates Response R-MIM is the same as the Service Delivery Location Details R-MIM with the addition of the QueryMatchObservation class.

hmdref.refName: Service Delivery Location Event Find Candidates Response

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Identifiers R-MIM defines the payload message used return all identifiers associated with a record in a service delivery location registry.
The Service Delivery Location Identifiers R-MIM is a reduced version of the Service Delivery Location Details R-MIM with the following changes:

list.item: Remove all attributes except id, code, name and statusCode
Remove all participations (spatialCoordinate and serviceDefinition)
Remove reflexive role links (part and partOf)
Remove all role links except for identifiedLocation
Remove all attributes except id, code and name
Remove LocatedEntityPartOf and LocatedEntityHasParts associations

rmim.name: Service Delivery Location Event Query By Details

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Location Registry Query By Details R-MIM defines the payload for a query-by-parameter message sent to a Service Delivery Location Registry when the query placer knows a set of location attributes.

The response to a Query By Details may potentially return many records so the SortControl class and the responseModalityCode, initialQuantity and initialQuantityCode attributes of the QueryByParameter class are included in the information model.
QueryByParameter - This is the entry point to the R-MIM. This class allows the query requester to specify how the query should be processed by the query fulfiller.

list.item: queryId - an identifier for the query. It is used to associate this query instance with both the initial response message and with later query interactions. Valuing queryId avoids the need for the QueryContinuation and QueryAck classes to carry as much detail information as is carried in the initial query.
statusCode - a code specifying the state of this query (based on the RIM Act class state machine), for example, active, aborted, completed.
modifyCode - indicates whether the subscription to a query is new or is being modified

responseElementGroupId - an identifier for the specific message type to be returned in the query response. The message type is constrained to the set of message types supported by the receiver responsibilities associated with the query interaction.
responseModalityCode - a code specifying the timing and grouping of the response instances
responsePriorityCode - a code specifying the time frame in which a response is expected
initialQuantity - the maximum size of the response that can be accepted by the requesting application.
initialQuantityCode - a code specifying the units associated with the initialQuantity
executionAndDeliveryTime - the time the response is to be returned

descriptive.p: SortControl - This class allows the query requester to specify the order in which the server should return multiple results.

list.item: sequenceNumber - the order of this elementName in the sort
elementName - the name of the element upon which the response should be sorted
directionCode - a code specifying the sort order (ascending, descending or none)

descriptive.p: MatchCriterionList - This collection of parameter items convey instructions to the query fulfiller. The associated parameter items are joined with OR logic.

list.item: MatchAlgorithm - This parameter conveys instructions to the query fulfiller specifying the preferred matching algorithm to use
MinimumDegreeMatch - This parameter conveys instructions to the query fulfiller specifying the minimum degree of match to use in filtering results
MatchWeight - This parameter conveys instructions to the query fulfiller specifying the desired weight to be assigned to parameter types in the matching process

descriptive.p: ParameterList - This collection of parameter items for the query, similar to the WHERE clause in a SQL query. A query message can include any combination of the parameters. Multiple instances of parameter item are combined with AND logic. Multiple values in the value attribute of a single parameter item instance are combined with OR logic.

list.item: SdlocName - a name for a service delivery location. The HL7 EN (entity name) data type is quite rich and the data type specification should be well understood before being used in a query. For example, the name use parameter can covey that a name is spelled phonetically or based on the SOUNDEX algorithm.

SdlocType - a code specifying a type of service delivery location drawn from the ServiceDeliveryLocationRoleType domain; for example FMC (Family medicine clinic), CCU (Coronary care unit), INV (Infertility clinic).
SdlocAddress - a postal or physical address for a service delivery location. This can be a full address or only an address component such as city or zip code.
SdlocStatusCode - a code specifying the state of a record in a location registry. The parameter is used to find records in a particular state such as "active" or "completed".

IdentifyingOrg - the name of an organization that has assigned its own identifier to a location. A location registry can hold identifiers used for a service delivery location by an organization other the organization that provides the services at the location.
IdentifyingOrgId - an identifier used for a location by the IdentifyingOrg

SdlocTerritorialAuthority - an identifier for a geographic region over which an organization has jurisdiction; for example, Region 4 of Alberta over which the Calgary Regional Health Authority has jurisdiction for heath matters.
SdlocService - a code specifying a type of service that may be performed at a service delivery location.

hmdref.refName: Service Delivery Location Event Query By Details

rmim.name: Service Delivery Location Event Query By Identifier

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Location Registry Query By Identifier R-MIM defines the payload for a query-by-parameter message sent to a service delivery location registry when the query placer knows an identifier for a location record in the registry.

The response to a Query By Identifier will typically return a single record so the SortControl class and the responseModalityCode, initialQuantity and initialQuantityCode attributes of the QueryByParameter class are not included in the information model.
QueryByParameter - The entry point to the R-MIM. This class allows the query requester to specify how the query should be processed by the query fulfiller.

list.item: queryId - an identifier for the query. It is used to associate this query instance with both the initial response message and with later query interactions. Valuing queryId avoids the need for the QueryContinuation and QueryAck classes to carry as much detail information as is carried in the initial query.
statusCode - a code specifying the state of this query (based on the RIM Act class state machine), for example, active, aborted, completed.
modifyCode - a code specifying whether the subscription to a query is new or is being modified

responseElementGroupId - an identifier for the specific message type to be returned in the query response. The message type is constrained to the set of message types supported by the receiver responsibilities associated with the query interaction.
responsePriorityCode - a code specifying the time frame in which a response is expected
executionAndDeliveryTime - the time the response is to be returned

descriptive.p: ParameterList - This collection of parameter items for the query, similar to the WHERE clause in a SQL query. A query message must include at least one ServiceDeliveryLocationIdentifier parameter item and may include DataSource parameter items. Multiple instances of parameter item are combined with AND logic. Multiple values in the value attribute of a single parameter item instance are combined with OR logic.

list.item: ServiceDeliveryLocationIdentifier - an identifier for a location record in a service delivery location registry

DataSource - the identifier for a data source (system). This supports data locator/aggregator type registries that respond to queries by farming the request out to other registries that hold the requested information.

hmdref.refName: Service Delivery Location Event Query By Identifier

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Activated payload message is used in state-transition notifications and state-transition requests for adding new records to a service delivery location registry.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Revised payload message is used in state-transition notifications and state-transition requests for revising existing records in a service delivery location registry.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Nullified payload message is used in the state-transition notification reporting nullification of an erroneously-entered record in a service delivery location registry.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Service Delivery Location Details payload message is used to return a complete or partial record from a service delivery location registry in response to a query.

hmd.name: Service Delivery Location Event Find Candidates Response

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Find Candidates Response payload message is used to return records from a service delivery location registry in response to a find candidates query. Each record includes an observation reporting how well the record matched the query parameters.

descriptive.name: Introduction
descriptive.p: This topic covers messages about Ambulatory Encounters in the Intent (appointment) mood and the Event mood. In an ambulatory encounter a patient visits a healthcare facility for diagnosis or treatment not requiring an overnight stay. However, to support use cases such as ambulatory surgery and observation patients, the Ambulatory Encounter information model includes an optional Accommodation associated with the patient's assigned location. In HL7 version 2.x terms, an ambulatory encounter is a visit with a Patient Class (PV1-2) of "outpatient".
This release supports all four unsolicited notification messages defined in the Scheduling domain. The message content is defined at:

item.p: Appointment New Notification (see )
Appointment Revise Notification (see )
Appointment Cancel Notification (see )
Appointment Reschedule Notification (see )

descriptive.p: This release supports five event notifications. The message content is defined at:

item.p: Begin Ambulatory Encounter (see )
Revise Ambulatory Encounter (see )
End Ambulatory Encounter (see )
Abort Ambulatory Encounter (see )
Nullify Ambulatory Encounter (see )

descriptive.p: The Patient Administration Technical Committee chose to limit scope in this first release by:

item.p: Limiting storyboards to the simplest cases
Excluding order/request messages

Excluding notification messages for state transitions "reactivate" and to/from "suspended" (see the Act State Diagram for Patient Administration Messages below; the unsupported states and transitions are grayed out in the diagram)

graphic.alt: Act State Diagram for Patient Encounter Messages

descriptive.p: The Patient Administration Technical Committee invites implementers with additional requirements to submit content proposals for future releases of the standard.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates the basic flow of an ambulatory encounter from scheduled, through active, to completed.
Exceptional events are described in other storyboards.

item.p: Canceling a scheduled ambulatory encounter is covered in .
Abnormal termination of an active ambulatory encounter is covered in .
Nullifying an erroneously reported ambulatory encounter is covered in .

descriptive.name: Ambulatory Encounter Basic Flow
descriptive.p: Mr. Adam Everyman is a 64-year-old male with severe chronic pain in his right hip. He called his primary care provider, Dr. Patricia Primary, for consultation. Dr. Primary's receptionist pulled Mr. Everyman's data up on the screen and created an appointment for the next afternoon at 3:00 PM [Trigger Event ].

Before his appointment, Dr. Patricia Primary's receptionist called to tell him that the appointment time needed to be changed. The new appointment was scheduled for 5:00 PM instead of 3:00 PM [Trigger Event ].

Ten minutes before his scheduled appointment, Mr. Everyman arrived at Dr. Primary's office and checked in with the receptionist. After he reviewed his contact and insurance information he was shown to an examination room [Trigger Event ].

Dr. Primary examined Mr. Everyman's inflamed hip. She saw that the encounter form incorrectly listed the reason for visit as "pain in left hip" instead of the right hip so she made a correction on the form. She gave Mr. Everyman a prescription for Naprosyn 500 mg. and told him that he did not need to schedule another visit.
Mr. Everyman returned to the front desk and gave the corrected encounter form to the receptionist who corrected the reason for visit [Trigger Event ].
The receptionist completed the check out process for Mr. Everyman [Trigger Event ].

During the office visit with Dr. Primary, Mr. Everyman mentioned that he did not want his family to worry about his condition. He asked Dr. Primary to be sure not to mention it when he and his wife came in for their next scheduled blood pressure check. When reviewing Mr. Everyman's record later that day, Dr. Primary noticed that the confidentiality request had not been recorded. Mr. Everyman's record was updated to note that the hip condition should not be mentioned to Mr. Everyman's family [Trigger Event ].

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Activate Notification
Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Reschedule Notification
Ambulatory Encounter Event Activate Notification
Ambulatory Encounter Event Revise Notification
Ambulatory Encounter Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates canceling an ambulatory encounter appointment.

descriptive.name: Ambulatory Encounter Appointment Abort
descriptive.p: After reviewing the radiologist's report Dr. Primary decided that her patient, Eve Everywoman, did not require the follow-up appointment she had scheduled. She had her receptionist call Eve and cancel her upcoming appointment for an office visit [Trigger Event ].

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates abnormal termination of an ambulatory encounter.

descriptive.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Abort
descriptive.p: Dr. Patricia Primary referred Mr. Adam Everyman to an orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Sara Specialize, for evaluation. Mr. Everyman checked in for his appointment with Dr. Specialize and was waiting in an examination room when Dr. Specialize was paged for an emergency at the hospital. Mr. Everyman agreed to return the next day instead of waiting for Dr. Specialize to return. The active ambulatory encounter was aborted [Trigger Event ].

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates nullifying an erroneously reported ambulatory encounter.

descriptive.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Nullify
descriptive.p: Dr. Patricia Primary's receptionist noticed that there were two encounters recorded for Mr. Everyman's visit. She realized that she had entered the encounter information twice. One of the duplicate encounters was marked as "entered in error" and was nullified [Trigger Event ].

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Schedule Ambulatory Encounter trigger event signals that a new ambulatory encounter appointment was scheduled.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Schedule Ambulatory Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 SIU^S12 - notification of new appointment booking event for an outpatient visit.

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Activate Notification

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Reschedule Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Reschedule Ambulatory Encounter Appointment trigger event signals that an ambulatory encounter appointment was rescheduled before the appointment began.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Reschedule Ambulatory Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 SIU^S13 notification of appointment rescheduling event for an outpatient visit.

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Reschedule Notification

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Revise Ambulatory Encounter Appointment trigger event signals that an ambulatory encounter appointment was modified before the appointment began.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Revise Ambulatory Encounter Appointment trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 SIU^S14 - notification of appointment modification event for an outpatient visit.

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Notification

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Cancel Ambulatory Encounter Appointment trigger event signals that an ambulatory encounter appointment was canceled before the appointment began.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Cancel Ambulatory Encounter Appointment trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 SIU^S15 - notification of appointment cancellation event for an outpatient visit.

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Abort Notification

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Begin Ambulatory Encounter trigger event signals that a new ambulatory encounter has started. This is variously called outpatient registration, ambulatory encounter check-in or admission for a short stay ambulatory encounter. If there was an appointment for this encounter then this trigger event also implicitly changes the status of the appointment to completed.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Begin Ambulatory Encounter trigger event is aligned with two HL7 2.4 events, the ADT^A04 - register a patient event signaling the start of an outpatient encounter and the ADT^A01 - admit/visit notification where the patient class in the PV1-2 is outpatient signaling the start of a short stay (less than 24 hours) admission. Note that in v3 a separate trigger event is required to activate a new patient record.

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Activate Notification

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Revise Ambulatory Encounter trigger event signals that information about an ambulatory encounter has changed.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Revise Ambulatory Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A08 - update patient information event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is outpatient. However, in v3 this trigger event only signals a change to encounter information, changes to a patient's demographic information are signaled by a Revise Patient Information trigger event.

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Revise Notification

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Abort Ambulatory Encounter trigger event signals that an ambulatory encounter was aborted prior to completion. Either the practitioner or the patient ended the encounter prematurely.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Abort Ambulatory Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A03 - discharge/end visit event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is outpatient and the discharge disposition in the PV1-36 is "Left against medical advice or discontinued care."

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Abort Notification

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The End Ambulatory Encounter trigger event signals that an ambulatory encounter ended normally. This is variously called end visit or ambulatory encounter check-out.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The End Ambulatory Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A03 - discharge/end visit event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is outpatient.

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Complete Notification

trigger.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Nullify Ambulatory Encounter trigger event signals that a previously-reported Begin Ambulatory Encounter notification was sent in error and has been nullified.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Nullify Ambulatory Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A11 - cancel admit/visit notification event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is outpatient.

intref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Intent Activate R-MIM defines the message used to report that a new ambulatory encounter appointment was scheduled.
The focal class (and entry point) to the Ambulatory Encounter Intent Activate R-MIM is the EncounterAppointment class. The attributes of encounter appointment are:

item.p: id - the unique identifier for this encounter appointment
code = AMB, says that is an appointment for an ambulatory encounter
statusCode = "active"
effectiveTime - the anticipated start and (optional) end time for the scheduled encounter
priorityCode - the admission urgency for the scheduled encounter
confidentialityCode - a code that controls the disclosure of information about this scheduled patient encounter

reasonCode - gives an explanation for the encounter appointment, other than the medical reason for the encounter in the pertinentInformation (diagnoses) described below. Examples of values here are "Medical Necessity", "Patient's Request" and "Dependency".

admissionReferralSourceCode - a code used to categorize the type of place or organization responsible for the patient immediately prior to their scheduled encounter; for example, in the United States, this is identified in UB-92 Form Locator 20, Source of Adm(ission). Detailed information about the admitted-from place or type of place is conveyed through the arrivedBy act relationship to the TransportationAppointment (see below).
lengthOfStayQuantity - expresses the expected quantity of time for the scheduled encounter
acuityLevelCode - a code depicting the anticipated acuity (complexity of patient care, resource intensiveness of the patient care) of a patient's medical condition upon arrival.

preAdmitTestInd - indicates whether tests or other preparations were scheduled in a preadmission encounter prior to this scheduled encounter. The actual appointment for the pre-admit tests can be related to this scheduled encounter with the reason act relationship (see below).
specialCourtesiesCode - a code identifying special courtesies to be extended to the patient (e.g., no courtesies, extended courtesies, professional courtesy, VIP courtesies).

specialArrangementCode - a code indicating the type of special arrangements to be provided for a patient encounter (e.g., wheelchair, stretcher, interpreter, attendant, seeing eye dog). This is not related to the AccommodationEvent.

descriptive.p: An encounter appointment can be the reason for another encounter appointment for tests or other preparation. The inpatient or ambulatory encounter appointment (target) is the reason for the pre-admission encounter appointment (source). Context conduction ensures that both appointments have the same subject (patient).
Encounter appointments can link to other acts:

item.p: AccommodationAppointment: the patient's assigned location at the beginning of the encounter, ServiceDeliveryLocation, may be linked to one or more AccommodationAppointment acts via a locationOf participation. Generally an ambulatory encounter would not include an AccommodationAppointment but it is included to support use cases such as ambulatory surgery and observation patients.

TransportationAppointment: the patient's scheduled arrival is linked to the encounter via an arrivedBy act relationship. The patient's mode of arrival can be sent as TransportationAppointment.text, the admitted-from location in a R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, and the time the patient is expected to arrive at the encounter site as the end of the TransportationAppointment.effectiveTime range. Context conduction ensures that the encounter appointment and the transportation appointment have the same subject (patient).
A_Account: the scheduled encounter can be linked to one or more patient accounts. Each account is sent in a separate A_Account CMET.

A_ObservationDx: the scheduled encounter can be linked to one or more admission diagnoses . Each diagnosis is sent in a separate A_ObservationDx CMET. Multiple admission diagnoses can be rank ordered using the pertinentInformation.priorityNumber.

A_Consent: the scheduled encounter can be linked to one or more consents granted by the patient or the patient's representative. Each consent is sent in a separate A_Consent CMET. Note, this s currently a placeholder CMET until the Medical Records TC completes work on medico-legal document modeling.

p.emph: Direct Participations in the Scheduled Encounter

descriptive.p: A number of entities play roles that participate directly in the scheduled encounter:

item.p: admitter: the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the scheduled encounter
responsibleParty: a healthcare provider organization that will hold clinical responsibility for the patient at the start of the scheduled encounter
location: the patient's assigned location at the start of the scheduled encounter
subject: the patient who is the subject of the scheduled encounter
referrer: the healthcare practitioner who requested the scheduled encounter to take place
consultant: an advisor who will participate in the scheduled encounter by performing evaluations and making recommendations
attender: the healthcare practitioner who will be primarily responsible for the patient at the start of the scheduled encounter
notificationContact: the patient's designated Emergency Contact for this scheduled encounter.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise R-MIM defines the message used to report that information about an ambulatory encounter appointment was revised before the encounter began.

Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise R-MIM differs from the Ambulatory Encounter Intent Activate R-MIM by excluding the statusCode attribute because state changes in EncounterAppointment are conveyed by the trigger event identified in the Trigger Event Control Act.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Reschedule R-MIM defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter appointment was rescheduled before the encounter began. The composite message changes the date-time of the scheduled encounter, allows changing the patient's initial assigned location and associated AccommodationAppointment, allows changing the details of the patient's arrivedBy planned transportation to the encounter, and conveys the reason the appointment was rescheduled.

The reason the appointment was rescheduled can be conveyed in the portion of the HL7 composite message. The reasonCode attribute of the ControlActProcess conveys a simple, coded reason. More comprehensive information about why the appointment was rescheduled may be conveyed in a A_DetectedIssue CMET associated with the ControlActProcess via a reasonOf act relationship.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Intent Abort R-MIM defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter appointment was canceled before the encounter began. The composite message aborts the encounter appointment, completes managed participations in the appointment, and conveys the reason the appointment was canceled.

The reason the appointment was canceled is conveyed in the portion of the HL7 composite message. The reasonCode attribute of the ControlActProcess conveys a simple, coded reason. More comprehensive information about why the appointment was canceled may be conveyed in a A_DetectedIssue CMET associated with the ControlActProcess via a reasonOf act relationship.
The focal class (and entry point) of the Ambulatory Encounter Intent Abort R-MIM is the EncounterAppointment class. The attributes of encounter are:

item.p: id - the unique identifier for this encounter appointment
code = AMB, says that this was an appointment for an ambulatory encounter
statusCode = "aborted"
reasonCode - gives an explanation for the encounter, other than the medical reason for the encounter. Examples of values here are "Medical Necessity", "Patient's Request" and "Dependency".
lengthOfStayQuantity - expresses the expected quantity of time for the scheduled encounter.

responsibleParty: the healthcare provider organization that was scheduled to hold clinical responsibility for care of the patient at the start of the scheduled encounter. An encounter abort completes the responsibleParty participation.

location: the patient's initial assigned location for the scheduled encounter. The location may have also linked the scheduled encounter to an AccommodationAppointment. An encounter abort completes the location participation and scheduled AccommodationAppointment.
attender: the healthcare practitioner who was scheduled to be primarily responsible for the patient at the start of the scheduled encounter. An encounter abort completes the attender participation.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Event Active R-MIM defines the message used to report that a new ambulatory encounter has started.
The focal class (and entry point) of the Ambulatory Encounter Event Activate R-MIM is the EncounterEvent class. The attributes of encounter are:

item.p: id - one or more unique identifiers for this encounter (for example, an "internal" id used only by computer systems and an "external" id for display to users)
code = AMB, says that this is an ambulatory encounter
statusCode = "active"

effectiveTime - a starting time representing the administrative onset of the encounter (e.g. admission, registration, patient arrival) and, optionally, an ending time representing the anticipated date-time of the patient's departure (e.g. discharge). All messages, except the "nullify" message, require at least a starting time.

activityTime - the total time interval for an encounter including preparation before the patient arrives and clean-up actions after the patient departs. This would probably be null in an encounter activate message.
priorityCode - the encounter admission urgency.
confidentialityCode - a code that controls the disclosure of information about this patient encounter.

reasonCode - gives an explanation for the encounter, other than the medical reason for the encounter in the pertinentInformation1 (diagnoses) described below. Examples of values here are "Medical Necessity", "Patient's Request" and "Dependency".

admissionReferralSourceCode - a code used to categorize the type of place or organization responsible for the patient immediately prior to their admission. In the US realm this references the UB92 FL 20 - Source of Admission value set.
lengthOfStayQuantity - expresses the expected quantity of time for the encounter.
dischargeDispositionCode - A code depicting the expected disposition of the patient at the time of discharge. In the US realm this references the UB92 FL 22 - Patient Status value set.
acuityLevelCode - a code depicting the acuity (complexity of patient care, resource intensiveness of the patient care) of a patient's medical condition upon arrival.

preAdmitTestInd - indicates whether tests or other preparations were done in a preadmission encounter prior to this admission. The actual encounter for the pre-admit tests can be related to the encounter with the reason act relationship (see below).
specialCourtesiesCode - a code identifying special courtesies extended to the patient (e.g., no courtesies, extended courtesies, professional courtesy, VIP courtesies).

specialArrangementCode - a code indicating the type of special arrangements provided for a patient encounter (e.g., wheelchair, stretcher, interpreter, attendant, seeing eye dog). This is not related to the AccommodationEvent.

descriptive.p: Encounters can relate to other encounters in three ways:

item.p: reason: this can link the encounter to one or more pre-admission ambulatory encounters for tests or other preparation. The inpatient or ambulatory encounter (target) is the reason for the pre-admission encounter (source). Context conduction ensures that all encounters have the same subject (patient). Note that the Encounter.preAdmitTestInd should also be set to "true".

sequelTo: this can link the encounter to a previous encounter for the same patient. Examples include: (1) a patient in an ambulatory encounter is admitted as an inpatient after an evaluation of the seriousness of the patient's condition, (2) an inpatient is discharged from an inpatient encounter directly to an ambulatory encounter as part of the same episode of care, (3) a patient is re-admitted to a healthcare facility. Context conduction ensures that both encounters have the same subject (patient).

componentOf: this can link the encounter to one or more sub-encounters performed within the main encounter. Examples include: (1) an outpatient visit includes clinical encounters with radiology and clinical specialists, (2) an emergency room visit includes encounters for two non-related issues (blurry vision in the eye and a sprained knee, causing the patient to be sent to an eye specialist and an orthopedist). Context conduction ensures that all encounters have the same subject (patient)

descriptive.p: Encounters can link to other acts:

item.p: AccommodationEvent: the patient's assigned location during an encounter, ServiceDeliveryLocation, can be linked to one or more AccommodationEvent acts via a locationOf participation. Generally an ambulatory encounter would not include an AccommodationEvent but it is included to support use cases such as ambulatory surgery and observation patients.

PatientTransportation: the patient's arrival can be linked to the encounter via an arrivedBy act relationship. The patient's mode of arrival can be sent as PatientTransportation.text, the admitted-from location in a R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, and the time patient arrived at the encounter site as the end of thePatientTransportation.effectiveTime range. Both the performer (person who transported the patient) and an escort can be sent in R_AssignedPerson [contact] CMETs. Context conduction ensures that the encounter and the transportation have the same subject (patient).

A_Appointment: the encounter can be linked to the appointment that scheduled the encounter. The scheduled encounter and the actual encounter should have the same value for type in Encounter.code. Context conduction ensures that the appointment and the encounter have the same subject (patient). Activation of the encounter event implicitly changes the status code of the appointment to completed.
A_Account: the encounter can be linked to one or more patient accounts. Each account is sent in a separate A_Account CMET.

A_ObservationDx: the encounter can be linked to one or more diagnoses. Each diagnosis is sent in a separate A_ObservationDx CMET. The encounter "activate" interaction would send an admission diagnosis (Observation.code of "ADMX" in the A_ObservationDx CMET). Multiple admission diagnoses can be rank ordered using the pertinentInformation1.priorityNumber.

A_Consent: the encounter can be linked to one or more consents granted by the patient or patient's representative. Each consent is sent in a separate A_Consent CMET. Note, this is currently a placeholder CMET until the Medical Records TC completes work on medico-legal document modeling.

ValuablesLocation: the encounter can be linked to one or more reports of patient valuables stored during the encounter. Each report is sent as a free text observation of the valuables and where they are stored during the encounter. If no valuables were stored for the patient then an ValuablesLocation can be sent with a negationInd of "true".

descriptive.p: A number of entities play roles that participate directly in the encounter:

item.p: admitter: the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the encounter, usually in the case of an inpatient encounter. Note: the admitter here must be the same as the author reported in the HL7 Trigger Event Control Act for the admission.

responsibleParty: the healthcare provider organization that holds clinical responsibility for care of the patient during the encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial responsibleParty participation.

location: the patient's assigned location during the encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial location participation. ServiceDeliveryLocation is a role played by a place at which services may be provided. A service delivery location may be either an incidental service delivery location (a place at which services may be provided without prior designation or authorization) or a dedicated service delivery location (a place that is intended to house the provision of services). Dedicated service delivery locations can be further characterized as either clinical (DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType) or non-clinical (DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType).
subject: the patient who is the subject of the encounter.
referrer: the healthcare practitioner who requested the encounter to take place.
consultant: an advisor participating in the encounter by performing evaluations and making recommendations.

attender: the healthcare practitioner who is primarily responsible for the patient during a period in time in the given encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial attender participation.
notificationContact: the patient's designated Emergency Contact for this encounter.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Event Revise R-MIM defines the message used to report that information about an ambulatory encounter has changed. The ambulatory encounter can be either active or completed.
Ambulatory Encounter Event Revise R-MIM differs from the Ambulatory Encounter Event Activate R-MIM in the following ways:

item.p: EncounterEvent does not include the statusCode attribute because state changes in EncounterEvent are conveyed by the trigger event identified in the Trigger Event Control Act.
responsibleParty - the encounter revise message includes the current responsibleParty but should not be used to change the active responsibleParty. This is done with a message derived from the .

discharger - the encounter revise message includes an optional discharger participation in EncounterEvent. The discharger is the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the ending of an encounter.
location - the encounter revise message includes the current location but should not be used to change the active location. This is done with a message derived from the .

The single arrivedBy act relationship from EncounterEvent to PatientTransportation is replaced with up to two transportedBy act relationships permitting both patient arrival and patient departure transportation events.
attender - the encounter revise message includes the current attender but should not be used to change the active attender. This is done with a message derived from the .

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Event Abort R-MIM defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter was aborted prior to normal completion. The composite message aborts the encounter, completes the managed participations in the encounter, and conveys the reason the encounter was aborted.

The reason the encounter was aborted is conveyed in the portion of the HL7 composite message. The reasonCode attribute of the ControlActProcess conveys a simple, coded reason. More comprehensive information about why the encounter was aborted may be conveyed in a A_DetectedIssue CMET associated with the ControlActProcess via a reasonOf act relationship.
The focal class (and entry point) of the Ambulatory Encounter Event Abort R-MIM is the EncounterEvent class. The attributes of encounter are:

item.p: id - one or more unique identifiers for this encounter (for example, an "internal" id used only by computer systems and an "external" id for display to users)
code = AMB, says that this is an ambulatory encounter
statusCode = "aborted"
effectiveTime - the time interval starting with the administrative onset of the encounter (e.g. admission, registration, patient arrival) and ending with the patient's departure (e.g. discharge).
activityTime - the total time interval for an encounter including preparation before the patient arrives and clean-up actions after the patient departs.
reasonCode - gives an explanation for the encounter, other than the medical reason. Examples of values here are "Medical Necessity", "Patient's Request" and "Dependency".
lengthOfStayQuantity - expresses the actual quantity of time for the encounter.

dischargeDispositionCode - A code depicting the disposition of the patient at the time of discharge (e.g., discharged to home, expired, against medical advice, etc.). In the US realm this references the UB92 FL 22 - Patient Status value set.

descriptive.p: Encounters can link to other acts:

item.p: AccommodationEvent: the patient's assigned location during an encounter, ServiceDeliveryLocation, can be linked to one or more AccommodationEvent acts via a locationOf participation. Generally an ambulatory encounter would not include an AccommodationEvent but it is included to support use cases such as ambulatory surgery and observation patients.

PatientTransportation: the patient's departure can be linked to the encounter act via a departedBy act relationship. The patient's mode of departure can be sent as PatientTransportation.text, the discharged-to location in a R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, and the time patient arrived (or is anticipated to arrive) at the discharged-to site as the end of thePatientTransportation.effectiveTime range. Both the performer (person who transported the patient) and an escort can be sent in R_AssignedPerson [contact] CMETs. Context conduction ensures that the encounter and the transportation have the same subject (patient).

descriptive.p: A number of entities play roles that participate directly in the encounter:

item.p: responsibleParty: the healthcare provider organization that holds clinical responsibility for care of the patient during the encounter. An encounter abort completes the current responsibleParty participation.
location: the patient's assigned location during the encounter. An encounter abort completes the current location participation.
subject: the patient who is the subject of the encounter.
attender: the healthcare practitioner who is primarily responsible for the patient during a period in time in the given encounter. An encounter abort completes the current attender participation.
notificationContact: the patient's designated Emergency Contact for this encounter in case they need to be contacted about the unexpected end of the encounter.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Event Complete R-MIM defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter has ended normally
Ambulatory Encounter Event Complete R-MIM differs from the Ambulatory Encounter Event Activate R-MIM in the following ways:

item.p: The EncounterEvent.statusCode is set to "completed".
The EncounterEvent.effectiveTime contains actual values for both start and end date-times instead of an anticipated end date-time.
The EncounterEvent.activityTime is more likely to contain a value.

The EncounterEvent.lengthOfStayQuantity, if valued, contains the actual, calculated quantity (the actual days quantity cannot be simply calculated from the admission and discharge dates because of possible leaves of absence) instead of the expected length of stay.
The EncounterEvent.dischargeDispositionCode, if valued, contains the actual discharge disposition instead of the expected discharge disposition.

The departedBy act relationship from EncounterEvent to PatientTransportation replaces the arrivedBy act relationship. The patient's mode of departure can be sent as PatientTransportation.text, the discharged-to location in a R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, and the time the patient departed from the encounter site as the start of thePatientTransportation.effectiveTime range and time the patient arrived (or is expected to arrive) at the discharged-to location as the end of the time range. Both the performer (person who transported the patient) and an escort can be sent in R_AssignedPerson [contact] CMETs. Context conduction ensures that the encounter and the transportation have the same subject (patient).
There is an optional discharger participation in EncounterEvent. The discharger is the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the ending of an encounter.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Ambulatory Encounter Event Nullify R-MIM defines the message used to report nullification of an erroneously entered ambulatory encounter. It includes only enough information to identify the nullified encounter.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that a new ambulatory encounter appointment was scheduled.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter appointment was modified before the encounter began.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter appointment was rescheduled before the encounter began.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter appointment was canceled before the encounter began. It includes only enough information to identify the canceled appointment and the reason it was canceled.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that a new ambulatory encounter has started.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that information about an ambulatory encounter has changed.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter was aborted prior to normal completion. It includes only enough information to identify the aborted encounter and the reason it was aborted.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that an ambulatory encounter has ended normally.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report nullification of an erroneously entered ambulatory encounter. It includes only enough information to identify the nullified encounter.

descriptive.name: Design Walk-through
descriptive.p: This message is used to report that a new ambulatory encounter appointment was scheduled.

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after an ambulatory encounter appointment is scheduled. An informer sends to a tracker a complete ambulatory appointment record, including related acts and participations.

teref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Activate Notification

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Reschedule Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after an ambulatory encounter appointment is rescheduled before the encounter takes place. An informer sends to a tracker enough information to identify the appointment, the new date and time, and any schedulable participations.

teref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Reschedule Notification

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after an ambulatory encounter appointment is revised before the encounter has started. An informer sends to a tracker a complete ambulatory appointment record, including related acts and participations.

teref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Revise Notification

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after an ambulatory encounter appointment is canceled before the encounter has started. An informer sends to a tracker enough information to identify the canceled appointment.

teref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Intent Abort Notification

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after a new ambulatory encounter starts. An informer sends to a tracker a complete ambulatory encounter record, including related acts and participations.

arref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Comprehensive Except Nullify Informer
Ambulatory Encounter Event Comprehensive Except Nullify Tracker

teref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Activate Notification

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after information about an ambulatory encounter changes (except for changes to Attending Practitioner, Patient Location and Responsible Organization participations that cause separate interactions). An informer sends to a tracker a complete ambulatory encounter record, including related acts and participations.

Ambulatory Encounter Event Comprehensive Except Nullify Tracker

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after an ambulatory encounter is aborted prior to completion. This could have been result of action by either the practitioner or the patient. An informer sends to a tracker information about the end of the encounter and the reason the encounter was aborted.

arref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Comprehensive Except Nullify Informer
Ambulatory Encounter Event Comprehensive Except Nullify Tracker

teref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Abort Notification

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after an ambulatory encounter ends. An informer sends to a tracker a complete ambulatory encounter record, including related acts and participations.

arref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Comprehensive Except Nullify Informer
Ambulatory Encounter Event Comprehensive Except Nullify Tracker

teref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Complete Notification

interaction.name: Ambulatory Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This interaction occurs after a previously reported Ambulatory Encounter Started interaction is nullified. An informer sends to a tracker enough information to identify the nullified encounter.

teref.refName: Ambulatory Encounter Event Nullify Notification

div3.head: Introduction & Scope
div3.p: The Patient Administration Inpatient Encounter topic defines messages about Inpatient Encounters in the intent (appointment) and event moods. In an inpatient encounter a patient is admitted by a hospital or equivalent facility, assigned to a location where patients generally stay at least overnight and provided with room, board, and continuous nursing service. In HL7 version 2.x terms, an inpatient encounter is a visit with a Patient Class (PV1-2) of "inpatient".
This document includes message specifications for:

list.item: Inpatient encounter appointment notifications for state transitions of activated and revised. The Scheduling and Logistics domain defines notifications for new, revised, rescheduled and canceled appointments. The Patient Administration domain defines an alternative message with additional content specifically for new and revised inpatient encounter appointments.
Inpatient encounter event notifications for state transitions of activated, revised, aborted, completed, reactivated and nullified
Inpatient encounter event notifications for user requests of link/unlink encounters for mother and baby, link/unlink encounters for donor and recipient, pending inpatient discharge.

div3.p: The Patient Administration Technical Committee chose to limit scope in this release by Limiting storyboards to the simplest cases, excluding order/request messages and excluding notification messages for state transitions to/from "new" and "suspended" (see the State Diagram below; the unsupported states and transitions are grayed out in the diagram):
The Patient Administration Technical Committee invites implementers with additional requirements to submit content proposals for future updates to the standard.

div3.head: Changes From Previous Release
div3.p: This Patient Administration Inpatient Encounter DSTU Update is an update to the existing Inpatient Encounter Topic of Patient Administration DSTU that passed ballot in the 2004JAN ballot cycle. This publication is an accumulation of changes approved within the Patient Administration Technical Committee through thee For Comment ballots (2004AUG, 2005JAN, 2005MAY), a thorough analysis of the inpatient information models and their constraints completed in July 2005, a Committee ballot (2005SEP) and new content approved at the September 2006 Working Group Meeting.

div4.head: New Interactions
div4.p: This update adds seven new interactions:

artref.alt: Encounters for Baby and Mother Linked
Encounters for Baby and Mother Unlinked
Encounters for Donor and Recipient Linked
Encounters for Donor and Recipient Unlinked

div4.head: Information Model Changes
div4.p: The following list identifies the specific changes made to the Active Inpatient Encounter and Revised Inpatient Encounter R-MIMs. The other information models are subsets of these two models.

list.item: The effectiveTime attribute of EncounterEvent was changed from Required 0..1 to Required 1..1
The priorityCode attribute of EncounterEvent was changed from optional 0..* to optional 0..1
The acuityLevelCode attribute of EncounterEvent was removed from the model
The responsibleParty participation in EncounterEvent was changed from Required 0..* to optional 0..1
The admitter participation in EncounterEvent was changed from Required 0..1 to Required 1..1 for the Active Inpatient Encounter R-MIM
The attender participation in EncounterEvent was changed from optional 0..* to Required 0..*
The sequenceNumber attribute was added to attender to support the use case where there is more than one attender participation active at a given time
The time attribute of referrer was removed from the model
The time attribute of consultant was changed from optional 0..1 to Required 1..1
The time attribute was added to notificationContact as optional 0..1
The location participation in EncounterEvent was changed from Required 0..1 to Required 1..*
The statusCode attribute of location was changed from optional 0..1 to Required 1..1
The name attribute was added to ServiceDeliveryLocation as optional 0..*
The statusCode attribute of ServiceDeliveryLocation was changed from Mandatory 1..1 to optional 0..1
The location playing the role of ServiceDeliveryLocation was changed from Mandatory 1..1 to optional 0..1
The moodCode of Accommodation was changed from event to x_ActMoodIntentEvent to support the use case of a planned accommodation for a pending patient location assignment
The code attribute of Accommodation was changed from optional 0..1 to Mandatory 1..1
The reasonCode attribute of Accommodation was changed from optional 0..* to optional 0..1
The act relationship from EncounterEvent to A_ObservationDx was changed from pertinentInformation to reason act relationship type
The target of the reference act relationship from EncounterEvent was changed from A_Account to A_AcccountGuarantor
The act relationship from EncounterEvent to ValuablesLocation was changed from pertinentInformation to itemStorage act relationship type
The text attribute of ValuablesLocation was removed from the model
The value attribute of ValuablesLocation was changed from optional 0..1 to Required 1..1
The PatientTransportation act was renamed TransportationEvent
The code attribute of TransportationEvent was changed from optional 0..1 to Required 1..1
The statusCode attribute of TransportationEvent was removed from the model
The priorityCode attribute of TransportationEvent was changed from optional 0..* to optional 0..1
The location participation in TransportationEvent was changed from optional 0..1 to optional 0..* to support multi-segment patient transportation events
The sequenceNumber attribute was added to TransportationEvent

A departedBy act relationship to TransportationIntent was added from EncounterEvent to support the use case where the patient's transportation after the encounter has been arranged when the patient is admitted
The act relationship between the focal encounter and a pre-admission encounter was reversed to make the focal encounter the target
The source act of the componentOf act relationship was changed from A_Encounter to A_CareEvent

Context conduction was remodeled
The ContextControlCode attribute was removed from act relationships inFulfillmentOf, sequelTo, arrivedBy, reason and componentOf
The ContextConductionInd attribute was added to act relationships reason, authorization, reference and itemStorage
The contextControlCode attribute was added to participations responsibleParty, admitter, attender, referrer, consultant, notificationContact and location

div3.head: Known Issues
div3.p: A number of the changes made to the inpatient information models are not backwards compatible.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates the basic flow of an inpatient encounter from scheduled, through active, to completed.
Exceptional events are described in other storyboards.

item.p: Canceling a scheduled inpatient admission is covered in .
Abnormal termination of an active inpatient encounter is covered in .
Nullifying an erroneously reported inpatient encounter is covered in .

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Basic Flow
descriptive.p: Mr. Adam Everyman's physician, Dr. Patricia Primary, called the Good Health Hospital to schedule an inpatient admission for Mr. Everyman for lung surgery. The clerk pulled Mr. Everyman's data up on the screen and created a scheduled encounter for June 27 [Interaction ].
The next day, the Good Health Hospital called Mr. Everyman to reschedule his admission from June 27 to June 29 because of a scheduling conflict with the surgeon Dr. Cutter [Interaction ].

Dr. Sara Specialize was tentatively scheduled to be the consulting pulmonologist for Mr. Everyman's admission for lung surgery but she was not available for the rescheduled admission date. The consulting pulmonologist was changed to Dr. Penny Puffer [Interaction ].

Mr. Everyman arrived via wheelchair at Good Health Hospital admitting office at 0600 on June 29, 2001 for an admission. He stated the reason he was being admitted: "for surgery on his lung". Dr. Primary referred Mr. Everyman to Dr. Cutter for thoracic surgery. Dr. Cutter was Mr. Everyman's attending physician. Alice, Admitting Clerk, accessed Mr. Everyman's appointment for the inpatient encounter and noted that he had arrived to fulfill the appointment. Alice noted that Mr. Everyman was a patient of the surgical service and would be staying on the fourth floor, ward B, room 1016, bed A. The admission type was "elective". Since Mr. Everyman has a history of heart problems, his cardiologist Dr. Patrick Pump is entered as the consulting physician for the inpatient encounter for Mr. Everyman. The admitting diagnosis "rule/out lung cancer" is also entered. Mr. Everyman stated that the emergency contact for this visit was his daughter Nancy Dahl. Alice entered the emergency contact name and phone number. Alice also noticed that there was a note attached to Mr. Everyman's record indicating that he is a large donor to Good Health Hospital and was to receive special courtesy during each stay. Mr. Everyman stated that he did not have any valuables on his person [Interaction ].

Later, Mr. Everyman called the admitting clerk, Alice, and informed her that he needed to change his emergency contact information because his daughter, Nancy Dahl, was called away unexpectedly. Mr. Everyman informed Alice that his emergency contact would be his son, James Everyman. Alice entered James' phone number and address [Interaction ].

Dr. Cutter performed thoracic surgery on Mr. Everyman in order to rule out lung cancer. After the surgery, Dr. Cutter consulted with Dr. Dunst, pulmonologist and determined that the surgical results indicated that Mr. Everyman does not have lung cancer. Dr. Cutter decided that Mr. Everyman could be discharged the next day to home and would require no immediate follow-up care.
On the day of Mr. Everyman's planned discharge, Christopher, nursing unit clerk, completed the discharge information for Mr. Everyman and discharged him from the GHH Inpatient Unit [Interaction ].

While reviewing the chart after Mr. Everyman's discharge, Dr. Cutter noticed that the discharge disposition was entered incorrectly and the record indicated that there was follow-up care required when in fact follow-up care was not required. The discharge disposition was corrected to indicate that there was no immediate follow-up care required [Interaction ].

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems after canceling a scheduled inpatient admission.

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Intent Abort
descriptive.p: Dr. Primary decided that Mr. Everyman's condition had improved significantly that he would not need lung surgery, after all. Dr. Primary's office phoned both Mr. Everyman and Good Health Hospital to inform them of the change. Alice, the Good Health Hospital Admissions clerk cancelled Mr. Everyman's scheduled inpatient admission[Interaction ].
