story.name: Inpatient Encounter Baby To Mother Link
story.familiarName: Encounters for Baby and Mother Linked

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems after the inpatient encounter for a new born baby has been linked to the inpatient encounter for the baby's mother.

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Link Baby To Mother
descriptive.familiarName: Encounters for Baby and Mother Linked
descriptive.p: Eve Everywoman arrived at Good Health Hospital admitting office at 0600 on June 29, 2001 in labor. Alice, Admitting Clerk, accessed Eve Everywoman's planned admission for the OB inpatient encounter and noted that she had arrived. Dr. Sara Specialize was Eve Everywoman's OB physician. Alice noted that Ms. Everywoman was a patient of the OB service and would be staying on the fourth floor, ward B, room 1016, bed A. The admission type was "obstetric". Ms. Everywoman stated that the emergency contact for this visit was her husband Mr. Adam Everyman. Alice entered the emergency contact name and phone number. [Interaction ].

Eve Everywoman gave birth to a baby girl. Alice, Admitting Clerk was notified that Eve Everywoman gave birth to a baby girl. The baby was healthy and did not need any specialized neonatal care so she was admitted as a healthy newborn and put into the nursery on the fourth floor, bed C for normal hospital tests. [Interaction ].
Alice, Admitting Clerk then linked the mother's and baby's encounters together for care and billing purposes. [Interaction ].

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Baby To Mother Unlink
descriptive.familiarName: Encounters for Baby and Mother Unlinked
descriptive.p: A little while after Alice the Admitting Clerk entered a "Link Encounter for Baby to Mother" for Eve Everywoman's baby she realized that she had mistakenly selected the inpatient encounter for Ava Everywoman. Alice unlinked the baby's encounter from the encounter for Ava Everywoman and linked the correct two encounters.

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Donor To Recipient Link
descriptive.familiarName: Encounters for Donor and Recipient Linked
descriptive.p: When Adam Everyman found that he needed a kidney transplant his sister, Eve Everywoman offered to donate one of her kidneys. On May 4, 2003 he received notice that his sister was a good match and the surgery was scheduled.

On June 4 Adam Everyman arrived at the Good Health Hospital admitting office at 0900 and was admitted as a patient of the Surgery service and assigned to the fourth floor, ward A, room 4123, bed A [Interaction ].

Later that day Eve Everywoman was also admitted and assigned to fourth floor, ward A, room 4321, bed B [Interaction ]. Alice, Admitting Clerk, then linked Eve's encounter to Adam's encounters together for care and billing purposes [Interaction ].

Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Link Donor To Recipient

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Donor To Recipient Unlink
descriptive.familiarName: Encounters for Donor and Recipient Unlinked
descriptive.p: A little while after Alice the Admitting Clerk entered a "Link Encounter for Donor to Recipient" for Eve Everywoman to Adam Everyman she realized that she had mistakenly selected the inpatient encounter for Abram Everyman. Alice unlinked the Eve Everywoman's encounter from the encounter for Abram Everyman and linked the correct two encounters.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems after an inpatient encounter has been aborted before completion.

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Abort
descriptive.p: Eve Everywoman, a 60-year-old female, presented at Good Health Hospital to the admitting department on the morning of her surgery. Alice, the admitting clerk admitted Ms. Everywoman for a surgical procedure. But, Ms. Everywoman was found to have high fever which would prevent her from having the surgery. The encounter was aborted and Ms.Everywoman was sent home [Interaction ].

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems that an erroneously reported inpatient encounter has been nullified.

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Nullify
descriptive.p: Mr. Everyman arrived at the Good Health Hospital admitting office for an inpatient admission. Alice Admitter, an admitting clerk, admitted Mr. Everyman. A patient identification band was printed and placed on Mr. Everyman's wrist but he noticed that the identification band had the wrong name. Mr. Everyman informed Alice that his name and age were wrong. Alice realized she had mistakenly admitted Jon Jones. Alice marked the encounter entry as "entered in error" [Interaction ] and then correctly processed the admission for Mr. Everyman.

story.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Reactivate

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems after an inpatient discharge has been canceled. The action could either be the result on an erroneous discharge or a decision not to discharge the patient for clinical reasons.

story.descriptive: Adam Everyman's discharge was processed as scheduled this morning. As he was being readied for departure he complained to the nurse about feeling dizzy. The nurse took his temperature and found that he had a fever. A decision was made to not allow Adam Everyman to leave. [Interaction with a ControlActProcess.reasonCode = "MEDNEC" (medical necessity) and, optionally, a related DetectedIssue].

Eve Everywoman was discharged this morning in error by Alice, Admitting Clerk. When Alice realized that she discharged the wrong patient, Alice reversed the discharge for Eve Everywoman. [Interaction with a ControlActProcess.reasonCode = "ER" (error)].

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Reactivate Notification

story.name: Inpatient Encounter Pending Discharge
story.descriptive: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems that an inpatient will soon be discharged.

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Notification Pending Discharge
descriptive.p: The province is currently in the midst of a SARS outbreak although no cases have yet been reported at Community Health Hospital. Adam Everyman arrives at Community Health Hospital with a fever and respiratory symptoms. As part of the admission process, hospital staff conducts a SARS risk factor assessment interview. As a result, Adam is admitted as a suspect SARS case. A few days later, Adam's wife arrives at the emergency department with a fever and respiratory symptoms. The ER staff report these admission findings to Paula Pasteur, the Infection Control Practitioner, who then contacts the public health agency.

The public health agency requests that Adam and his wife be transferred to Good Health Hospital, which has been designated as the local SARS treatment center. The Province has strict transfer control protocols for SARS cases that require the hospital to make arrangements and get approval from the Provincial Transfer Authorization Center (PTAC). Once this is done Paula (the ICP) sends a notification of the upcoming transfer to Nurse Nightingale at the public health unit. Since the newly designated SARS hospital lies within her jurisdiction, Nightingale will continue to monitor these cases.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Pending Discharge

story.name: Inpatient Encounter Pending Discharge Cancel
story.descriptive: This storyboard demonstrates notifying tracking systems that a previously-reported pending inpatient discharge is being canceled.

descriptive.name: Inpatient Encounter Pending Discharge Cancel
descriptive.p: Adam Everyman is admitted to Good Health Hospital for total hip replacement surgery. Mr. Everyman lives alone so arrangements are made for a two-week stay in an extended care facility following the surgery. On the fourth day after successful surgery Dr. Attend decides that Mr. Everyman can be discharged after two more days. The Discharge Coordinator notifies the extended care facility of Mr. Everyman's pending discharge. The next evening Mr. Everyman complained to the nurse about feeling dizzy. The nurse took his temperature and found that he had a fever. Dr. Attend decided that Mr. Everyman's discharge should be delayed so the Discharge Coordinator initiated a notification to the extended care facility.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Pending Discharge Cancel

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Appointment Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This trigger event signals that an inpatient admission was scheduled.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Schedule Inpatient Encounter trigger event maps to three HL7 2.4 events, the ADT^A05 - pre-admit a patient, the ADT^A14 - pending admit, and the SIU^S12 - notification of new appointment booking for an inpatient admission.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Appointment Activate Notification

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Appointment Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This trigger event signals that a scheduled inpatient admission was modified prior to the admission.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Revise Inpatient Encounter Appointment trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 SIU^S14 - notification of appointment modification event for an inpatient visit.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Appointment Revise Notification

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This trigger event signals that a patient was admitted to an inpatient encounter. If there was an appointment for this encounter then this trigger event also implicitly changes the status of the appointment to completed.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Begin Inpatient Encounter is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A01 admit/visit notification event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is inpatient.

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Pending Discharge Notification
trigger.descriptive: This trigger event signals of a plan to discharge an inpatient when the patient has not yet left the healthcare facility.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Pending Inpatient Discharge Notification is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A16 pending discharge notification event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is inpatient.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Pending Discharge

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Pending Discharge Notification Cancel
trigger.descriptive: This trigger event signals that a planned inpatient discharge was canceled.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Pending Inpatient Discharge Notification is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A25 cancel pending discharge notification event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is inpatient.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Pending Discharge Cancel

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This trigger event signals that information about an inpatient encounter has changed.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Revise Inpatient Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A08 - update patient information event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is inpatient. However, in v3 this trigger event only signals a change to encounter information, changes to a patient's demographic information are signaled by a Revise Patient Information trigger event.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This trigger event signals that an inpatient encounter was aborted prior to a normal discharge. Either the practitioner or the patient ended the encounter prematurely.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Abort Inpatient Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A03 - discharge/end visit event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is inpatient and the discharge disposition in the PV1-36 is "Left against medical advice or discontinued care."

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Abort Notification

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This trigger event signals that an inpatient was discharged.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The End Inpatient Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A03 - discharge/end visit event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is inpatient.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Complete Notification

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Reactivate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This trigger event signals that a previously-reported inpatient discharge was canceled before the patient was released from the hospital. This trigger event could be either the result of an erroneously-reported inpatient discharge or because a decision was made not to discharge the patient after all.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Cancel Inpatient Discharge trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 v2.4 ADT^13 Cancel Discharge notification event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is inpatient.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Reactivate Notification

trigger.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This trigger event signals that a previously-reported inpatient admission notification was sent in error and has been nullified.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Nullify Inpatient Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A11 - cancel admit/visit notification event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is inpatient.

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Active Inpatient Encounter Appointment R-MIM defines the message used in notifications about active inpatient encounter appointments. It is used by both "activate" and "revise" notifications.
The focal class (and entry point) is the EncounterAppointment class. The attributes of encounter appointment are:

item.p: id - the unique identifier for this encounter appointment
code = IMP, says that is an appointment for an inpatient encounter
statusCode = "active"
effectiveTime - the anticipated start and (optional) end time for the scheduled encounter
priorityCode - the admission urgency for the scheduled encounter
confidentialityCode - a set of codes that control the disclosure of information about this scheduled patient encounter

reasonCode - gives an explanation for the encounter appointment, other than the medical reason for the encounter in the pertinentInformation (diagnoses) described below. Examples of values here are "Medical Necessity", "Patient's Request" and "Dependency".

admissionReferralSourceCode - a code used to categorize the type of place or organization responsible for the patient immediately prior to their scheduled encounter; for example, in the United States, this is identified in UB-92 Form Locator 20, Source of Adm(ission). Detailed information about the admitted-from place or type of place is conveyed through the arrivedBy act relationship to the TransportationAppointment (see below).
lengthOfStayQuantity - expresses the expected quantity of time for the scheduled encounter

preAdmitTestInd - indicates whether tests are required prior to this encounter. The encounter(s) for the pre-admit tests can be related to this scheduled encounter with the reason act relationship (see below).
specialCourtesiesCode - a code identifying special courtesies to be extended to the patient (e.g., no courtesies, extended courtesies, professional courtesy, VIP courtesies).

specialArrangementCode - a code indicating the type of special arrangements to be provided for a patient encounter (e.g., wheelchair, stretcher, interpreter, attendant, seeing eye dog). This is not related to the AccommodationEvent.

descriptive.p: An encounter appointment can be the reason for another encounter appointment for tests or other preparation. The pre-admission encounter appointment (source) has reason of the inpatient or inpatient encounter appointment (target). Context conduction ensures that both appointments have the same subject (patient).
Encounter appointments can link to other acts:

item.p: AccommodationAppointment: the patient's assigned location at the beginning of the encounter, ServiceDeliveryLocation, may be linked to one or more AccommodationAppointment acts via a locationOf participation. A patient may request or need a specific accommodation such as ward, private, or semi-private accommodations for (a part of) the encounter. The AccommodationAppointment.reasonCode tells if the accommodation is a medical necessity or the result of a patient request.

TransportationAppointment: the patient's scheduled arrival is linked to the encounter via an arrivedBy: participation. The patient's mode of arrival can be sent as TransportationAppointment.text, the admitted-from location in a R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, and the time the patient is expected to arrive at the encounter site as the end of the TransportationAppointment.effectiveTime range. Context conduction ensures that the encounter appointment and the transportation appointment have the same subject (patient).
A_AccountGuarantor: the scheduled encounter can be linked to one or more patient accounts. Each account is sent in a separate A_AccountGuarantor CMET.

A_ObservationDx: the scheduled encounter can be linked to one or more admission diagnoses . Each diagnosis is sent in a separate A_ObservationDx CMET. Multiple admission diagnoses can be rank ordered using the pertinentInformation.priorityNumber.

A_Consent: the scheduled encounter can be linked to one or more consents granted by the patient or the patient's representative. Each consent is sent in a separate A_Consent CMET. Note, this s currently a placeholder CMET until the Medical Records TC completes work on medico-legal document modeling.

p.emph: Direct Participations in the Scheduled Encounter

descriptive.p: A number of entities play roles that participate directly in the scheduled encounter:

item.p: admitter: the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the scheduled encounter
responsibleParty: a healthcare provider organization that will hold clinical responsibility for the patient at the start of the scheduled encounter
location: the patient's assigned location at the start of the scheduled encounter
subject: the patient who is the subject of the scheduled encounter
referrer: the healthcare practitioner who requested the scheduled encounter to take place
consultant: an advisor who will participate in the scheduled encounter by performing evaluations and making recommendations
attender: the healthcare practitioner who will have responsibility for overseeing the patient's care at the start of the scheduled encounter
notificationContact: the patient's designated Emergency Contact for this scheduled encounter.

p.emph: In addition to the R-MIM walk-through above, attribute-level documentation can be found in the Table and Excel views for each Hierarchical Message Description and Message Type derived from this R-MIM.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Active Inpatient Encounter R-MIM defines the message used to report that a new inpatient encounter has startedan inpatient encounter has been activated or reactivated.

This information model is for inpatient patient encounters in the active state. In a inpatient patient encounter the patient is admitted by a hospital or equivalent facility, assigned to a location where patients generally stay at least overnight and provided with room, board, and continuous nursing service.

The statusCode ("active"), and code ("IMP") should be considered fixed. Status changes are communicated using the provided trigger events and a change in encounter type requires completing the existing encounter and activating a new encounter of the appropriate type.

In an active encounter the following, if valued, should be interpreted as anticipated values: the end of the effectiveTime interval, the end of the activityTime interval, the lengthOfStayQuantity, and the dischargeDispositionCode.
Encounters can relate to other encounters in three ways:

item.p: reasonOf: this can link the focal encounter (target) to one or more pre-admission patient encounters for tests (source). Note that the preAdmitTestInd for the focal encounter should also be set to "true".

sequelTo: this can link the focal encounter (source) to a previous encounter (target) for the same patient. Examples include: (1) a patient in an ambulatory encounter is admitted as an inpatient after an evaluation of the seriousness of the patient's condition, (2) an inpatient is discharged from an inpatient encounter directly to an ambulatory encounter as part of the same episode of care, (3) a patient is re-admitted to a healthcare facility.

componentOf: this can link the focal encounter (target) to a super-encounter (source) of which it is a component. Examples include: (1) an outpatient visit includes clinical encounters with radiology and clinical specialists, (2) an emergency room visit includes encounters for two non-related issues (blurry vision in the eye and a sprained knee, causing the patient to be sent to an eye specialist and an orthopedist).an overall care event (source) of which it is a component. The care event represents someone (generally a health care practitioner) taking responsibility for some aspect of a patient's health; examples include primary/preferred care provider, case manager.

descriptive.p: Encounters can link to other acts:

item.p: AccommodationProcess: the patient's assigned location during an encounter, ServiceDeliveryLocation, can be linked to one or more AccommodationEvent acts via a locationOf participation. A patient may request or need a specific accommodation such as ward, private, or semi-private accommodations for (a part of) the encounter. The reasonCode tells if the accommodation is a medical necessity or the result of a patient request. A planned accommodation with a moodCode of intent can be sent for a pending patient location assignment.

TransportationEvent (arrivedBy): describes the patient's arrival at the encounter site. The patient's mode of arrival can be sent as TransportationEvent.code, the admitted-from location in an origin type location participation of R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, locations transited on the way to the encounter site as via type location participations, and the time patient arrived at the encounter site as the end of theTransportationEvent.effectiveTime interval. Both the performer (person who transported the patient) and an escort can be sent in R_AssignedPerson [contact] CMETs. The name of a transportation service can be sent as the name of the Organization scoping the AssignedPerson role.

TransportationIntent (departedBy): describes the patient's anticipated departure from the encounter site at the end of the encounter. The patient's mode of departure can be sent as TransportationEvent.code, the discharged-to location in an destinationtype location participation of R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, locations expected to be transited as via type location participations, the time the patient is expected to depart from the encounter site as the start of theTransportationEvent.effectiveTime interval. Both the expected performer (person who will transport the patient) and an escort can be sent in R_AssignedPerson [contact] CMETs. The name of a transportation service can be sent as the name of the Organization scoping the AssignedPerson role.

A_Appointment (inFulfillmentOf): the focal encounter can be linked to the appointment that scheduled it. The scheduled encounter and the actual encounter should have the same value for type in Encounter.code. Activation of the encounter event implicitly changes the status code of the appointment to completed.
A_AccountGuarantor (reference): the encounter can be linked to one or more patient accounts. Each account is sent in a separate A_AccountGuarantor CMET.

A_ObservationDx (reason): the encounter can be linked to one or more diagnoses. Each diagnosis is sent in a separate A_ObservationDx CMET. The encounter "activate" interaction would send an admission diagnosis (Observation.code of "ADMX" in the A_ObservationDx CMET). Multiple admission diagnoses can be rank ordered using the reason.priorityNumber.

A_Consent (authorization): the encounter can be linked to one or more consents granted by the patient or patient's representative. Each consent is sent in a separate A_Consent CMET. Note, this is currently a placeholder CMET until the Medical Records TC completes work on medico-legal document modeling.

ValuablesLocation (itemStorage): the encounter can be linked to one or more reports of patient valuables stored during the encounter. Each report is sent as a free text observation of the valuables and where they are stored during the encounter. A ValuablesLocation.negationInd of "true" indicates that the item described in ValuablesLocation.value was not stored for safekeeping during the encounter. The item could have been retained by the patient or taken by a family member of friend accompanying the patient.

descriptive.p: A number of entities play roles that participate directly in the encounter:

item.p: admitter: the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the encounter, usually in the case of an inpatient encounter. Note: the admitter here must be the same as the author reported in the HL7 Trigger Event Control Act for the admission.

responsibleParty: the healthcare provider organization that holds clinical responsibility for care of the patient during the encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial responsibleParty participation.

location: the patient's assigned location during the encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial active location participation and, optionally, one or more pending location participations. ServiceDeliveryLocation is a role played by a place at which services may be provided. A service delivery location may be either an incidental service delivery location (a place at which services may be provided without prior designation or authorization) or a dedicated service delivery location (a place that is intended to house the provision of services). Dedicated service delivery locations can be further characterized as either clinical (DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType) or non-clinical (DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType).
subject: the patient who is the subject of the encounter.
referrer: the healthcare practitioner who requested the encounter to take place.
consultant: an advisor participating in the encounter by performing evaluations and making recommendations.

attender: the healthcare practitioner who has responsibility for overseeing a patient's care during the patient encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial attender participation. If the encounter has more than one active attender then the sequenceNumber attribute should be valued.
notificationContact: the patient's designated Emergency Contact for this encounter.

p.emph: In addition to the R-MIM walk-through above, attribute-level documentation can be found in the Table and Excel views for each Hierarchical Message Description and Message Type derived from this R-MIM.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Revised Inpatient Encounter R-MIM defines the message used to report that information about an inpatient encounter has changed. However, certain changes are not permitted. The Revised Inpatient Encounter message:

list.item: SHALL NOT change the subject (patient) of the encounter
SHALL NOT change the Encounter.id; additional identifiers may be added but none may be changed
SHALL NOT change the Encounter.statusCode; notification of a state change in EncounterEvent SHALL be conveyed by the trigger event identified in the Trigger Event Control Act.

descriptive.p: The Revised Inpatient Encounter R-MIM is similar to the Active Inpatient Encounter R-MIM with the following changes to support encounters in the completed state:

list.item: The R-MIM includes an optional discharger participation in EncounterEvent. The discharger is the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the ending of an encounter.
The arrivedBy act relationship to TransportationEvent and departedBy act relationship to TransportationIntent is replaced with a single transportedBy act relationship to TransportationEvent.

p.emph: In addition to the R-MIM walk-through above, attribute-level documentation can be found in the Table and Excel views for each Hierarchical Message Description and Message Type derived from this R-MIM.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Linked Inpatient Encounters R-MIM defines the message used to report that inpatient encounters for two different patients are linked (or unlinked) for care and billing purposes.

The entry point is the source EncounterEvent that is in some way dependent on the target encounter in the A_Encounter [identified] CMET. For example, a newborn baby's encounter is linked to the mother's encounter, or an organ donor's encounter is linked to the organ recipient's encounter. The source encounter is linked to the target encounter via a pertinentInformation act relationship.

The same message type is used for bothSeparate message types are used for linking and unlinking encounters. When linking two encounters the pertinentInformation act relationship is sent with an update mode of "added". When unlinking two encounters the same message is sent but the pertinentInformation act relationship is sent with an update mode of "deleted".

p.emph: In addition to the R-MIM walk-through above, attribute-level documentation can be found in the Table and Excel views for each Hierarchical Message Description and Message Type derived from this R-MIM.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Aborted Inpatient Encounter R-MIM defines the message used to report an inpatient encounter was aborted prior to normal completion.

The Aborted Inpatient Encounter R-MIM includes only the encounter attributes and associations that can be changed by aborting an encounter. The reason the encounter was aborted is conveyed in the Trigger Event Control Act portion of the HL7 composite message. The reasonCode attribute of the ControlActProcess conveys a simple, coded reason. More comprehensive information about why the encounter was aborted may be conveyed in a A_DetectedIssue CMET associated with the ControlActProcess via a reasonOf act relationship.

item.p: The EncounterEvent.statusCode is set to "aborted".
The EncounterEvent.effectiveTime contains actual values for both start and end date-times instead of an anticipated end date-time.
The EncounterEvent.activityTime is more likely to contain a value.

The EncounterEvent.lengthOfStayQuantity, if valued, contains the actual, calculated quantity (the actual days quantity cannot be simply calculated from the admission and discharge dates because of possible leaves of absence) instead of the expected length of stay.
The EncounterEvent.dischargeDispositionCode, if valued, contains the actual discharge disposition instead of the expected discharge disposition.
The departedBy act relationship links EncounterEvent to TransportationEvent.
The patient's notificationContact is included to permit sending the emergency contact who was notified when the encounter was aborted.
The receiving application is responsible for completing or aborting the three managed participations in the encounter -- attender, responsibleParty, and location .

p.emph: In addition to the R-MIM walk-through above, attribute-level documentation can be found in the Table and Excel views for each Hierarchical Message Description and Message Type derived from this R-MIM.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Completed Inpatient Encounter R-MIM defines the message used to report that an inpatient encounter has ended normally.
The Completed Inpatient Encounter R-MIM includes only the encounter attributes and associations that can be changed by encounter completion:

item.p: The EncounterEvent.statusCode is set to "completed".
The EncounterEvent.effectiveTime contains actual values for both start and end date-times instead of an anticipated end date-time.
The EncounterEvent.activityTime is more likely to contain a value.

The EncounterEvent.lengthOfStayQuantity, if valued, contains the actual, calculated quantity (the actual days quantity cannot be simply calculated from the admission and discharge dates because of possible leaves of absence) instead of the expected length of stay.
The EncounterEvent.dischargeDispositionCode, if valued, contains the actual discharge disposition instead of the expected discharge disposition.
The departedBy act relationship links EncounterEvent to TransportationEvent.
There is a discharger participation in EncounterEvent. The discharger is the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the ending of an encounter.

The reason act relationship can convey one or more discharge diagnoses. Each diagnosis is sent in a separate A_ObservationDx CMET. The reason.priorityNumber specifies rank order if more than one discharge diagnosis is sent.
The receiving application is responsible for completing the three managed participations in the encounter -- attender, responsibleParty, and location .

p.emph: In addition to the R-MIM walk-through above, attribute-level documentation can be found in the Table and Excel views for each Hierarchical Message Description and Message Type derived from this R-MIM.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines notification messages about active inpatient encounter appointments.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that a new inpatient encounter has started.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that information about an inpatient encounter has changed.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that an inpatient encounter was aborted prior to normal completion. It includes only enough information to identify the aborted encounter and the reason it was aborted.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the message used to report that an inpatient encounter has ended normally.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD defines the messages used to report that inpatient encounters for two different patients are linked (or unlinked) for care and billing purposes.

descriptive.name: Design Walk-through
descriptive.p: This message is used to report that an inpatient admission was scheduled. It contains a complete inpatient appointment record, including related acts and participations.

Inpatient Encounter Appointment Revise Notification

Inpatient Encounter Event Reactivate Notification

descriptive.name: Design Walk-through

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification
Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Pending Discharge Cancel
Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Pending Discharge

intref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Design Walk-through
descriptive.p: This message is used to report that an inpatient encounter ended normally.

Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Link Baby To Mother

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Appointment Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: In inpatient scheduling system sends this notification when an inpatient admission is scheduled. The payload is a complete inpatient appointment record with related acts and participations.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Appointment Activate Notification

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Appointment Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient scheduling system sends this notification when a scheduled inpatient admission is revised before the encounter has started. The payload is a complete inpatient appointment record with related acts and participations.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Appointment Revise Notification

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification when a patient is admitted to an inpatient encounter. The payload is a complete inpatient encounter record with related acts and participations.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Activate Notification

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification when information about an inpatient encounter changes (except for changes to Attending Practitioner, Patient Location and Responsible Organization participations that cause separate interactions). The payload is a complete inpatient encounter record with related acts and participations.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Link Baby To Mother
interaction.familiarName: Encounters for Baby and Mother Linked

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification after the inpatient encounter for a newborn baby is linked to the inpatient encounter for the baby's mother for care and billing purposes. A separate interaction is defined for each type of encounter link because the same two encounters could be linked in more than one way. For example, a mother could also donate part of her liver to her newborn infant. They payload contains enough information to identify the two encounters and an associating ActRelationship with an update mode of "added".

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Link Baby To Mother Notification
teref.refFamiliarName: Link Encounters for Mother and Baby

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Link Donor To Recipient
interaction.familiarName: Encounters for Donor and Recipient Linked

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification after the inpatient encounter for an organ donor is linked to the inpatient encounter for the organ recipient for care and billing purposes. A separate interaction is defined for each type of encounter link because the same two encounters could be linked in more than one way. For example, a mother could also donate part of her liver to her newborn infant. The payload contains enough information to identify the two encounters and an associating ActRelationship with an update mode of "added".

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Link Donor To Recipient Notification
teref.refFamiliarName: Link Encounters for Recipient and Donor

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Pending Discharge Cancel

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: A user initiates a notification that a previously reported pending inpatient discharge notification is being canceled. The payload contains a snapshot of the encounter following the action.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Pending Discharge Notification Cancel

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Pending Discharge

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: A user initiates a notification that an inpatient will soon be discharged. The payload is a Revised Inpatient Encounter message type. In this notification interaction the encounter remains in the event mood and the statusCode remains active. However, discharge-related attributes and associations, if valued, have the following interpretations:

list.item: The end of the EncounterEvent.effectiveTime interval is the anticipated discharge date and time.
The end of the EncounterEvent.activityTime interval is the anticipated end of the post-encounter clean-up activities.
The dischargeDispositionCode is the anticipated disposition of the patient at the end of the encounter; for example, discharged to home.
The lengthOfStayQuantity is the anticipated quantity of time for the encounter.
The discharger participation in EncounterEvent. is the healthcare practitioner who is or will be authorizing the end of the encounter.
The departedBy act relationship to TransportationIntent describes the planned departure of the patient from the encounter site.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Pending Discharge Notification

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Unlink Baby To Mother
interaction.familiarName: Encounters for Baby and Mother Unlinked

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification after an erroneous link between the inpatient encounter for a newborn baby and the inpatient encounter for the baby's mother was deleted. A separate interaction is defined for each type of encounter unlink because the same two encounters could be linked in more than one way. For example, a mother could also donate part of her liver to her newborn infant. The payload contains enough information to identify the two encounters and an associating ActRelationship with an update mode of "delete".

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Link Baby To Mother Notification Cancel
teref.refFamiliarName: Unlink Encounters for Mother and Baby

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Notification Unlink Donor To Recipient
interaction.familiarName: Encounters for Donor and Recipient Unlinked

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification after an erroneous link between the inpatient encounter for an organ donor and the inpatient encounter for the organ recipient was deleted. A separate interaction is defined for each type of encounter unlink because the same two encounters could be linked in more than one way. For example, a mother could also donate part of her liver to her newborn infant. The payload contains enough information to identify the two encounters and an associating ActRelationship with an update mode of "deleted".

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Revise Link Donor To Recipient Notification Cancel
teref.refFamiliarName: Unlink Encounters for Recipient and Donor

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification after an inpatient encounter is aborted prior to completion. This could have been result of action by either the practitioner or the patient. The payload contains information about the end of the encounter and the reason the encounter was aborted.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Abort Notification

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification after an inpatient is discharged. The payload contains encounter attributes and associations that can be changed by encounter completion.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Complete Notification

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Reactivate Notification
interaction.descriptive: An inpatient encounter informer sends this notification after a previously reported inpatient discharge action is canceled. The payload contains a snapshot of the restored inpatient encounter.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Reactivate Notification

interaction.name: Inpatient Encounter Event Nullify Notification
interaction.descriptive: This notification occurs after a previously reported Inpatient Encounter Started interaction is nullified.

teref.refName: Inpatient Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Introduction
descriptive.p: This topic covers messages about Emergency Encounters in the Event mood. In an emergency encounter a patient is admitted for immediate evaluation and therapy provided until the patient can be referred to his or per personal practitioner for further care. In HL7 version 2.x terms, an emergency encounter is a visit with a Patient Class (PV1-2) of "emergency". Because emergency encounters are not planned, no appointment or associated preadmission encounter is included in the information models.
This release supports five event notifications. The message content is defined at:

item.p: Begin Emergency Encounter (see )
Revise Emergency Encounter (see )
End Emergency Encounter (see )
Abort Emergency Encounter (see )
Nullify Emergency Encounter (see )

descriptive.p: The Patient Administration Technical Committee chose to limit scope in this first release by:

item.p: Limiting storyboards to the simplest cases
Excluding order/request messages

Excluding notification messages for state transitions "reactivate" and to/from "suspended" (see the Act State Diagram for Patient Administration Messages below; the unsupported states and transitions are grayed out in the diagram)

graphic.alt: Act State Diagram for Patient Encounter Messages

descriptive.p: The Patient Administration Technical Committee invites implementers with additional requirements to submit content proposals for future releases of the standard.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates the basic flow of an emergency encounter from active to completed.
Exceptional events are described in other storyboards.

item.p: Abnormal termination of an emergency encounter is covered in .
Nullifying an erroneously reported emergency encounter is covered in .

descriptive.name: Emergency Encounter Basic Flow
descriptive.p: Adam Everyman arrived at Good Health Hospital emergency room via ambulance. Mr. Everyman was in respiratory distress and had an accelerated heart beat. The physician on duty, Dr. Eric Emergency, decided Mr. Everyman should be treated at this time. Mr. Everyman was checked-in for an ER visit. Christopher Clerk, the emergency room clerk, found Mr. Everyman's record in the GHH Patient Registry and created the emergency check-in [Trigger Event ].

The GHH ER clerk, Christopher, reviewed the contact information in Adam Everyman's patient record with him. Mr. Everyman stated that he needed to change his emergency contact information. Mr. Everyman's daughter was out of town so Mr. Everyman informed Christopher that he wanted to put his son, James Everyman, down as the emergency contact. He provided Christopher with James' phone number and address [Trigger Event ].

The GHH ER specialist, Dr. Eric Emergency decided that after a nebulizer treatment Mr. Everyman was stable and was ready to be checked-out. Dr. Emergency noted that Mr. Everyman needed to schedule a follow-up visit with Dr. Puffer, pulmonologist.
The GHH ER clerk completed the check-out information for Mr. Everyman and checked him out of the GHH Emergency Room [Trigger Event ].
Upon post check-out review, the Medical Records director discovered a diagnosis coding error. She corrected the coding to accurately reflect the diagnosis [Trigger Event ].

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Activate Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Revise Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates aborting an emergency encounter.

descriptive.name: Emergency Encounter Event Abort
descriptive.p: Eve Everywoman, a 60-year-old female, presented at Good Health Hospital Emergency Department for treatment of a laceration. The ER clerk checked in Ms. Everywoman. Ms. Everywoman was examined by the triage nurse, who judged that her wound was not serious and told her to take a seat. After two hours Ms. Everywoman told the clerk that she did not want to wait any longer and left without seeing a physician. The clerk aborted Ms. Everywoman's active emergency encounter [Trigger Event ].

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates nullifying an erroneously reported emergency encounter.

descriptive.name: Emergency Encounter Event Nullify
descriptive.p: Mr. Everyman arrived at the Good Health Hospital Emergency room. Alice Admitter, ER Clerk, checked in Mr. Everyman. A patient identification band was printed and placed on the Mr. Everyman's wrist but he noticed that the identification band had the wrong name. Mr. Everyman informed Alice that his name and age were wrong. Alice realized she has mistakenly entered the emergency encounter under the wrong patient, Jon Jones. Alice marked the encounter entry as "entered in error" [Trigger Event ] and correctly checked in Mr. Everyman.

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see and their relationships in the Version 3 Guide.

Emergency Encounter Event Revise Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An Emergency Encounter Normal Tracker receives all normal interactions for emergency encounters in the Event mood (excludes nullify). This application role is singled out since not all systems may be capable of processing nullification messages.

arref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Comprehensive Except Nullify Tracker

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Activate Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Revise Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Complete Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An Emergency Encounter Comprehensive Informer sends all notification messages for emergency encounters in the Event mood. It encompasses the Emergency Encounter Normal Informer and the Emergency Encounter Nullification Informer application roles.

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Activate Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Revise Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Complete Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Abort Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An Emergency Encounter Comprehensive Tracker receives all notification messages for emergency encounters in the Event mood.

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Activate Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Revise Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Complete Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Abort Notification
Emergency Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

trigger.name: Emergency Encounter Event Activate Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Begin Emergency Encounter trigger event signals that a new emergency encounter started. This is sometimes called an emergency admission.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Begin Emergency Encounter trigger event is aligned with two HL7 2.4 events, the ADT^A04 - register a patient event and the ADT^A01 - admit/visit notification. In both cases the patient class in the PV1-2 is emergency.

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Activate Notification

trigger.name: Emergency Encounter Event Revise Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Revise Emergency Encounter trigger event signals that information about an emergency encounter has changed.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Revise Emergency Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A08 - update patient information event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is emergency. However, in v3 this trigger event only signals a change to encounter information, changes to a patient's demographic information are signaled by a Revise Patient Information trigger event.

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Revise Notification

trigger.name: Emergency Encounter Event Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Abort Emergency Encounter trigger event signals that an emergency encounter was aborted prior to completion. Either the practitioner or the patient ended the encounter prematurely.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Abort Emergency Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A03 - discharge/end visit event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is emergency and the discharge disposition in the PV1-36 is "Left against medical advice or discontinued care."

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Abort Notification

trigger.name: Emergency Encounter Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The End Emergency Encounter trigger event signals that an emergency encounter ended normally. This is variously called end visit or emergency encounter check-out.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The End Emergency Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A03 - discharge/end visit event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is emergency.

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Complete Notification

trigger.name: Emergency Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Nullify Emergency Encounter trigger event signals that a previously-reported Begin Emergency Encounter notification was sent in error and has been nullified.

descriptive.name: V2 Reference
descriptive.p: The Nullify Emergency Encounter trigger event is most closely aligned with the HL7 2.4 ADT^A11 - cancel admit/visit notification event where the patient class in the PV1-2 is emergency.

intref.refName: Emergency Encounter Event Nullify Notification

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Emergency Encounter Event Active R-MIM defines the message used to report that a new emergency encounter has started.
The focal class (and entry point) of the Emergency Encounter Event Activate R-MIM is the EncounterEvent class. The attributes of encounter are:

item.p: id - one or more unique identifiers for this encounter (for example, an "internal" id used only by computer systems and an "external" id for display to users)
code = EMER, says that this is an emergency encounter
statusCode = "active"

effectiveTime - a starting time representing the administrative onset of the encounter (e.g. admission, registration, patient arrival) and, optionally, an ending time representing the anticipated date-time of the patient's departure (e.g. discharge). All messages, except the "nullify" message, require at least a starting time.

activityTime - the total time interval for an encounter including preparation before the patient arrives and clean-up actions after the patient departs. This would probably be null in an encounter activate message.
priorityCode - the encounter admission urgency.
confidentialityCode - a code that controls the disclosure of information about this patient encounter.

reasonCode - gives an explanation for the encounter, other than the medical reason for the encounter in the pertinentInformation1 (diagnoses) described below. Examples of values here are "Medical Necessity", "Patient's Request" and "Dependency".

admissionReferralSourceCode - a code used to categorize the type of place or organization responsible for the patient immediately prior to their admission. In the US realm this references the UB92 FL 20 - Source of Admission value set.
lengthOfStayQuantity - expresses the expected quantity of time for the encounter.
dischargeDispositionCode - A code depicting the expected disposition of the patient at the time of discharge. In the US realm this references the UB92 FL 22 - Patient Status value set.
acuityLevelCode - a code depicting the acuity (complexity of patient care, resource intensiveness of the patient care) of a patient's medical condition upon arrival.
specialCourtesiesCode - a code identifying special courtesies extended to the patient (e.g., no courtesies, extended courtesies, professional courtesy, VIP courtesies).

specialArrangementCode - a code indicating the type of special arrangements provided for a patient encounter (e.g., wheelchair, stretcher, interpreter, attendant, seeing eye dog). This is not related to the AccommodationEvent.

descriptive.p: Encounters can relate to other encounters in three ways:

item.p: sequelTo: this can link the encounter to a previous encounter for the same patient. Examples include: (1) a patient in an emergency encounter is admitted as an emergency after an evaluation of the seriousness of the patient's condition, (2) an emergency is discharged from an emergency encounter directly to an emergency encounter as part of the same episode of care, (3) a patient is re-admitted to a healthcare facility. Context conduction ensures that both encounters have the same subject (patient).

componentOf: this can link the encounter to one or more sub-encounters performed within the main encounter. Examples include: (1) an outpatient visit includes clinical encounters with radiology and clinical specialists, (2) an emergency room visit includes encounters for two non-related issues (blurry vision in the eye and a sprained knee, causing the patient to be sent to an eye specialist and an orthopedist). Context conduction ensures that all encounters have the same subject (patient)

descriptive.p: Encounters can link to other acts:

item.p: AccommodationEvent: the patient's assigned location during an encounter, ServiceDeliveryLocation, can be linked to one or more AccommodationEvent acts via a locationOf participation. A patient may request or need a specific accommodation such as ward, private, or semi-private accommodations for (a part of) the encounter. The AccommodationEvent.reasonCode tells if the accommodation is a medical necessity or the result of a patient request.

PatientTransportation: the patient's arrival can be linked to the encounter via an arrivedBy act relationship. The patient's mode of arrival can be sent as PatientTransportation.text, the admitted-from location in a R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, and the time patient arrived at the encounter site as the end of thePatientTransportation.effectiveTime range. Both the performer (person who transported the patient) and an escort can be sent in R_AssignedPerson [contact] CMETs. Context conduction ensures that the encounter and the transportation have the same subject (patient).
A_Account: the encounter can be linked to one or more patient accounts. Each account is sent in a separate A_Account CMET.

A_ObservationDx: the encounter can be linked to one or more diagnoses. Each diagnosis is sent in a separate A_ObservationDx CMET. The encounter "activate" interaction would send an admission diagnosis (Observation.code of "ADMX" in the A_ObservationDx CMET). Multiple admission diagnoses can be rank ordered using the pertinentInformation1.priorityNumber.

A_Consent: the encounter can be linked to one or more consents granted by the patient or patient's representative. Each consent is sent in a separate A_Consent CMET. Note, this is currently a placeholder CMET until the Medical Records TC completes work on medico-legal document modeling.

ValuablesLocation: the encounter can be linked to one or more reports of patient valuables stored during the encounter. Each report is sent as a free text observation of the valuables and where they are stored during the encounter. If no valuables were stored for the patient then an ValuablesLocation can be sent with a negationInd of "true".

descriptive.p: A number of entities play roles that participate directly in the encounter:

item.p: admitter: the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the encounter, usually in the case of an emergency encounter. Note: the admitter here must be the same as the author reported in the HL7 Trigger Event Control Act for the admission.

responsibleParty: the healthcare provider organization that holds clinical responsibility for care of the patient during the encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial responsibleParty participation.

location: the patient's assigned location during the encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial location participation. ServiceDeliveryLocation is a role played by a place at which services may be provided. A service delivery location may be either an incidental service delivery location (a place at which services may be provided without prior designation or authorization) or a dedicated service delivery location (a place that is intended to house the provision of services). Dedicated service delivery locations can be further characterized as either clinical (DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType) or non-clinical (DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType).
subject: the patient who is the subject of the encounter.
referrer: the healthcare practitioner who requested the encounter to take place.
consultant: an advisor participating in the encounter by performing evaluations and making recommendations.

attender: the healthcare practitioner who is primarily responsible for the patient during a period in time in the given encounter. The encounter "activate" interaction activates the initial attender participation.
notificationContact: the patient's designated Emergency Contact for this encounter.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Emergency Encounter Event Revise R-MIM defines the message used to report that information about an emergency encounter has changed. The emergency encounter can be either active or completed.
Emergency Encounter Event Revise R-MIM differs from the Emergency Encounter Event Activate R-MIM in the following ways:

item.p: EncounterEvent does not include the statusCode attribute because state changes in EncounterEvent are conveyed by the trigger event identified in the Trigger Event Control Act.
responsibleParty - the encounter revise message includes the current responsibleParty but should not be used to change the active responsibleParty. This is done with a message derived from the .

discharger - the encounter revise message includes an optional discharger participation in EncounterEvent. The discharger is the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the ending of an encounter.
location - the encounter revise message includes the current location but should not be used to change the active location. This is done with a message derived from the .

The single arrivedBy act relationship from EncounterEvent to PatientTransportation is replaced with up to two transportedBy act relationships permitting both patient arrival and patient departure transportation events.
attender - the encounter revise message includes the current attender but should not be used to change the active attender. This is done with a message derived from the .

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Emergency Encounter Event Abort R-MIM defines the message used to report that an emergency encounter was aborted prior to normal completion. The composite message aborts the encounter, completes the managed participations in the encounter, and conveys the reason the encounter was aborted.

The reason the encounter was aborted is conveyed in the portion of the HL7 composite message. The reasonCode attribute of the ControlActProcess conveys a simple, coded reason. More comprehensive information about why the encounter was aborted may be conveyed in a A_DetectedIssue CMET associated with the ControlActProcess via a reasonOf act relationship.
The focal class (and entry point) of the Emergency Encounter Event Abort R-MIM is the EncounterEvent class. The attributes of encounter are:

item.p: id - one or more unique identifiers for this encounter (for example, an "internal" id used only by computer systems and an "external" id for display to users)
code = EMER, says that this is an emergency encounter
statusCode = "aborted"
effectiveTime - the time interval starting with the administrative onset of the encounter (e.g. admission, registration, patient arrival) and ending with the patient's departure (e.g. discharge).
activityTime - the total time interval for an encounter including preparation before the patient arrives and clean-up actions after the patient departs.
reasonCode - gives an explanation for the encounter, other than the medical reason for the encounter. Examples of values here are "Medical Necessity", "Patient's Request" and "Dependency".
lengthOfStayQuantity - expresses the actual quantity of time for the encounter.

dischargeDispositionCode - A code depicting the disposition of the patient at the time of discharge (e.g., discharged to home, expired, against medical advice, etc.). In the US realm this references the UB92 FL 22 - Patient Status value set.

descriptive.p: Encounters can link to other acts:

item.p: AccommodationEvent: the patient's assigned location during an encounter, ServiceDeliveryLocation, can be linked to one or more AccommodationEvent acts via a locationOf participation. Generally an emergency encounter would not include an AccommodationEvent but it is included to support use cases such as emergency surgery and observation patients.

PatientTransportation: the patient's departure can be linked to the encounter act via a departedBy act relationship. The patient's mode of departure can be sent as PatientTransportation.text, the discharged-to location in a R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, and the time patient arrived (or is anticipated to arrive) at the discharged-to site as the end of thePatientTransportation.effectiveTime range. Both the performer (person who transported the patient) and an escort can be sent in R_AssignedPerson [contact] CMETs. Context conduction ensures that the encounter and the transportation have the same subject (patient).

descriptive.p: A number of entities play roles that participate directly in the encounter:

item.p: responsibleParty: the healthcare provider organization that holds clinical responsibility for care of the patient during the encounter. An encounter abort completes the current responsibleParty participation.
location: the patient's assigned location during the encounter. An encounter abort completes the current location participation.
subject: the patient who is the subject of the encounter.
attender: the healthcare practitioner who is primarily responsible for the patient during a period in time in the given encounter. An encounter abort completes the current attender participation.
notificationContact: the patient's designated Emergency Contact for this encounter in case they need to be contacted about the unexpected end of the encounter.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Emergency Encounter Event Complete R-MIM defines the message used to report that an emergency encounter has ended normally
Emergency Encounter Event Complete R-MIM differs from the Emergency Encounter Event Activate R-MIM in the following ways:

item.p: The EncounterEvent.statusCode is set to "completed".
The EncounterEvent.effectiveTime contains actual values for both start and end date-times instead of an anticipated end date-time.
The EncounterEvent.activityTime is more likely to contain a value.

The EncounterEvent.lengthOfStayQuantity, if valued, contains the actual, calculated quantity (the actual days quantity cannot be simply calculated from the admission and discharge dates because of possible leaves of absence) instead of the expected length of stay.
The EncounterEvent.dischargeDispositionCode, if valued, contains the actual discharge disposition instead of the expected discharge disposition.

The departedBy act relationship from EncounterEvent to PatientTransportation replaces the arrivedBy act relationship. The patient's mode of departure can be sent as PatientTransportation.text, the discharged-to location in a R_LocationLocatedEntity CMET, and the time the patient departed from the encounter site as the start of thePatientTransportation.effectiveTime range and time the patient arrived (or is expected to arrive) at the discharged-to location as the end of the time range. Both the performer (person who transported the patient) and an escort can be sent in R_AssignedPerson [contact] CMETs. Context conduction ensures that the encounter and the transportation have the same subject (patient).
There is an optional discharger participation in EncounterEvent. The discharger is the healthcare practitioner that required/authorized the ending of an encounter.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Emergency Encounter Event Nullify R-MIM defines the message used to report nullification of an erroneously entered ambulatory encounter. It includes only enough information to identify the nullified encounter.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Introduction
descriptive.p: This topic covers messages about Home Health Encounters in the Intent (appointment) mood and the Event mood. In a home health encounter clinical care is provided or supervised by a practitioner at the patient's home. Because home health encounters do not take place in a healthcare facility, no transportation or accommodation information is included in the information models. HL7 version 2.x does not include any equivalent messages in its ADT chapter.
This release supports all four unsolicited notification messages defined in the Scheduling domain. The message content is defined at:

item.p: Appointment New Notification (see )
Appointment Revise Notification (see )
Appointment Cancel Notification (see )
Appointment Reschedule Notification (see )

descriptive.p: This release supports five event notifications. The message content is defined at:

item.p: Begin Home Health Encounter (see )
Revise Home Health Encounter (see )
End Home Health Encounter (see )
Abort Home Health Encounter (see )
Nullify Home Health Encounter (see )

descriptive.p: The Patient Administration Technical Committee chose to limit scope in this first release by:

item.p: Limiting storyboards to the simplest cases
Excluding order/request messages

Excluding notification messages for state transitions "reactivate" and to/from "suspended" (see the Act State Diagram for Patient Administration Messages below; the unsupported states and transitions are grayed out in the diagram)

graphic.alt: Act State Diagram for Patient Encounter Messages

descriptive.p: The Patient Administration Technical Committee invites implementers with additional requirements to submit content proposals for future releases of the standard.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates the basic flow of a home health encounter from scheduled, through active, to completed.
Exceptional events are described in other storyboards.

item.p: Canceling a home health appointment is covered in .
Abnormal termination of an active home health encounter is covered in .
Nullifying an erroneously reported home health encounter is covered in .

descriptive.name: Home Health Encounter Basic Flow
descriptive.p: Adam Everyman has been an inpatient at Good Health Hospital for the past five days. His physician decided to discharge Mr. Everyman but felt he needed home health follow up. The Home Health Care Agency scheduled a nurse and a time to evaluate Mr. Everyman. The Agency scheduled the visit for the day Mr. Everyman was scheduled to go home [Trigger Event ].

The day Mr. Everyman was scheduled to go home he developed a fever and his inpatient discharge was delayed for a day. This was communicated to the Home Health Care Agency coordinator who rescheduled Mr. Everyman's first home health visit [Trigger Event ].

Later, Adam Everyman called Hannah Helpful, the Home Health Care Agency clerk, and informed her that he needed to change his emergency contact information. His daughter was going away on vacation and so he wanted her to put his son, James Everyman, down as the emergency contact and he provided Hannah with James' phone number and address [Trigger Event ].
The Home Health Care Agency nurse arrived at Mr. Everyman's home at the scheduled date and time to assess his status and admitted him into the system [Trigger Event ].

When Hannah Helpful, the Home Health Care Agency clerk previously updated Mr. Everyman's emergency contact information, she had entered the phone number for James Everyman incorrectly. When the information was reviewed with Adam Everyman, he pointed out that the emergency contact phone number was incorrect. The Home Health Care Agency nurse noted the change and the patient record was updated. [Trigger Event ].

Dr. Patricia Primary decided that Adam Everyman's condition had improved such that he no longer needed home health services. On orders from Dr. Primary, the Home Health Care Agency discharged Mr. Everyman [Trigger Event ].

After completion of Adam Everyman's home health visits, a post discharge review by the Home Health Care Agency Medical Records director discovered a diagnosis coding error. She entered the record and revised the coding to accurately reflect the diagnosis [Trigger Event ].

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates canceling a home health encounter appointment.

descriptive.name: Home Health Encounter Intent Abort
descriptive.p: Dr. Primary decided that Mr. Everyman's condition had improved such that he did not need the home health services she had scheduled. Dr. Primary informed Mr. Everyman and the Home Health Care Agency of the change. The Home Health Agency canceled Mr. Everyman's scheduled appointment. [Trigger Event ].

intref.refName: Home Health Encounter Intent Abort Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates abnormal termination of a home health encounter.

descriptive.name: Home Health Encounter Event Abort
descriptive.p: Adam Everyman was a patient receiving home health services from the Home Health Care Agency. On Tuesday the HHCA visiting nurse was in the middle of her weekly visit with Mr. Everyman when she received an urgent page to see another patient in the neighborhood. The nurse arranged to return to see Mr. Everyman in two days and then left [Trigger Event ].

intref.refName: Home Health Encounter Event Abort

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates nullifying an erroneously reported home health encounter.

descriptive.name: Home Health Encounter Event Nullify
descriptive.p: Adam Everyman was discharged from the hospital. Home health services were requested by his physician. The Home Health Care Agency intake nurse saw Mr. Everyman and determined that he could benefit from home health visits. Once at home the HHCA nurse met Mr. Everyman, registered him and scheduled his appointments. But, before the next visit occurred, the nurse found that two home health encounters were recorded for Mr. Everyman. One of the duplicate encounters was marked as "entered in error" and was nullified [Trigger Event ].
